crashed in a fireball.Federal authorities are still investigating the accident.The National Transportation Safety Board has not concluded what caused the crash on the outskirts of Los Angeles County but said there was no sign of mechanical failure in the Sikorsky S-. A final report is not expected for months.Vanessa hit the aircrafts owner, Island Express, with a -page lawsuit.The complaint - which also lists daughters Natalia, Bianka and Capri as plaintfs - was filed on the same day Vanessa delivered a heartbreaking eulogy for her husband and daughter at a memorial in Los Angeles.The firm and the pilot, Defendant Zobayan, were described as wanton, willful, callous, reckless and depraved in the court document.The owners of the doomed helicopter Island Express Holdings responded to the complaint by stating Kobe and Gigi were fully aware of the risks they were taking when they decided to fly.They claim Vanessa has no case against them — in part because the foggy weather conditions were an “act of god.In its response to the lawsuit allegations, the company states: Kobe Bryant and GB [Gigi] had actual knowledge of all of the circumstances, particular dangers, and an appreciation of the risks involved and the magnitude thereof, and proceeded to encounter a known risk, and voluntarily assumed the risk of the accident, injury.... thereby barring or reducing [Vanessas] claim for damages.Bryant is the only NBA player to have his team retire two numbers in his honor. title: space force plane rocket secret military mission
story: The space plane lted off on top of an Atlas V rocket from the Cape Canaveral Air Force Station in Florida at around .am.The newest military branch was set to launch the space plane on Saturday around .am and again at .am, but bad weather prevented the launch both times.Space Force officials said the space plane launch is dedicated to those working on the front lines to combat the coronavirus.Our invincible American spirit drives us to motivate, collaborate, and innovate together to overcome adversity, Secretary of the Air Force Barbara Barrett said in a statement.In dedicating this mission to the nations healthcare workers, first responders, and essential personnel, the Department celebrates those who are keeping America Strong.John Raymond, chief general of the Space Force, said: The US Space Force and United Launch Alliance salute each American serving on the frontlines in our fight against COVID-.We are proud to dedicate the upcoming launch of USSF- to showcase American resolve and national unity during these challenging times.Its unclear what is aboard the plane, but officials have said its carrying a satellite built by Air Force cadets.Sundays scheduled mission was the sixth for the X-B, but the second mission for the Space Force.The Space Force was officially established in December and is the first new military service since the Air Force launched in .The , airmen and civilians that make up the Space Force are technically part of the Air Force — which previously oversaw offensive operations in space.But President Donald Trump has made it clear he sees the newest service as critical to the future of American defense.On Friday, the Space Forces flag was unveiled in the Oval Office.Its dark blue and white and includes elements intended to title: astrazeneca virus vaccine 30m doses september uk
story: DRUGS giant AstraZeneca will make  million doses of the Oxford coronavirus vaccine by Septemberit works - and the UK will be the first to get it. Business Secretary Alok Sharma this evening announced a global licensing deal had been signed between Oxford University and the pharma firm as part of a £million plan to vaccinate half the UK population.The firm will make million doses of the vaccine over timeit proves to prevent the infection - and half of Brits would be in line to get one.In order to succeed as soon as possible, Mr Sharma announced a fresh £m in cash for the two universities to scale up production of their ground-breaking potential vaccines.£. million is earmarked for Oxford and £.million for Imperial.This will mean the UK will be the first country to get access to the Oxford vaccine, should it be successful.Oxford has finished its first phase of human trials this week - with everyone planned having received their vaccine doses on schedule.Imperial are on track to start their trial in June, with a second one by October.It came as:Business Secretary Mr Sharma said today: Our scientists are at the forefront of vaccine development. This deal with AstraZeneca means thatthe Oxford University vaccine works, people in the UK will get the first access to it, helping to protect thousands of lives.The agreement will deliver  million doses in total, ensuring that in addition to supporting our own people, we are able to make the vaccines available to developing countries at the lowest possible cost.The UK continues to lead the global response to find a vaccine, and the government is backing our scientists to do this as quickly as possible.And Health Secretary Matt Hancock added: Our injection of a further £ million for a #coronavirus vaccine is a great step forward in our national effort.However, Boris Johnson has been stark with the public - admitting we may not get a vacccine.Hes said in the past: A mass vaccine or treatment may be more than a year away. Indeed, in a worst-case scenario, we may never find a vaccine.However, Professor Sarah Gilbert, who is working on a vaccine with a team at the university, is confident it will work and says it could be ready in just months.As the nation faces the reality of living for months with coronavirus restrictions, a successful vaccine holds the key to the end of isolation measures.Currently, there is no vaccine or treatment availale for Covid- but doctors across the globe are testing current anti-viral drugs to seethey can beat coronavirus.Today Mr Sharma revealed that six more drugs would go into tests to seethey can have an effect on coronavirus symptoms.About  research groups are pursuing vaccines with nearly a dozen in early stages of human trials or poised to start.Microsoft billionaire Bill Gates, for example, has committed hundreds of millions of dollars to developing a vaccine through the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.

title: miracle baby born same date mum sis
story: Kylee-Beau was delivered nine days late on April , which was mum Heidi Eton’s th birthday.It was also the date of sister Ellie-May’s ninth — and the birthday of Heidi’s aunt.Bookies William Hill said the odds of that happening through three generations were  million-to-one.Chef Heidi said she named her lb daughter in tribute to the NHS’s rainbow logo — and staff at the hospital in Hillingdon, West London.She said: “The staff were magnicent and I wanted to say thank you to them. So I had the idea of having Beau — it reminds me of the word beautul.”“I was so wrapped up in having Kylee-Beau that it was only after she was born and the nurse said the date, that I remembered it was my birthday as well.“It totally slipped my mind. I told the midwe and then said it was also Ellie-Mays birthday and my auntie’s.“We joked about it being an expensive month for presents.”Because of coronavirus Heidi’s partner John Hall had to drop her off at the hospital then come back  hours later just as Kylee-Beau was born.Heidi said: “Luckily we only live five minutes from the hospital so I gave him a bell and he made it to the delivery suite where he cut the cord and was able to hold her.“I feel so blessed. title: headteachers union reopen school
story: A TEACHING union has told heads to open their school gates next month after being reassured by government scientists it will be safe.After a week of wrangling, the Association of School and College Leaders gave their members the go-ahead to restart classes.But the National Association of Head Teachers offered advice to their members — leaving it up to them to start planning.Both unions urged heads to introduce the phased reopening of primary schools, rather than having all pupils in at once.The announcement will delight the Department for Education, which wants reception and Years  and  back on June .Officials want to emulate the success of Denmark, where primary schools have opened successfully following coronavirus shutdowns with social distancing and smaller classes.It comes as a major study showed the risk of coronavirus spreading in schools was extremely low, The Times reports.Research revealed only two caught the virus after  infected students and teachers in  schools came into close contact with  people.The findings showed transmission among children and teachers is limited in classrooms in the first study of its kind.Further discussions will take place between officials and unions this week to iron out the final issues, The Sun understands.ASCL general secretary Geoff Barton said he was reassured by feedback from government scientic advisers on Friday and supported members in preparing for reopening schools from June .But he said he was concerned by the idea that all eligible primary children could be asked tofull time and called for the Government to be flexible. He said the union would back any schools which decided they were not ready to reopen.The NAHT said it was sensible to plan for a phased reopening.But it added: “There is a dference between planning for aand implementing a .”General secretary Paul Whiteman called for “clear evidence on the level of risk pupils, parents and staff may pose to one another”.But the National Education Union refused to back down on schools reopening until testing, tracking and tracing was in place.Yesterday, Cabinet Minister Michael Gove urged unions to let staff get back to the “job they love.”Asked by the BBC’s Andrew Marrhe could guarantee their safety, he said he was “confident teachers will be safe”.He said it was extremely unlikely a school was the source of an outbreak and it was important children get back their one chance at education as soon as possible.In a direct plea to unions, he said: “If you really care about children you will want them to be in school, you will want them to be learning, you’ll want them to have new opportunities.”Dr Soumya Swaminathan, chief scientist at the World Health Organisation, backed the Government’s position yesterday. She said: “What we have seen in countries where schools have remained open is that there have not been big outbreaks in schools.“And where there have been, it’s been associated with events where a lot of people gather — not in regular classrooms — and it’s often been associated with an adult, who’s had the infection and spread it.“It does seem from what we know now that children are less capable of spreading it eventhey get infection and certainly are at very low risk of getting ill from the disease.”She called on officials to discuss the risks with parents, teachers and pupils to ensure they were all comfortable with ing to class.There is a real risk for the most vulner-able, in families less able to support them with home learning, that there will be an even bigger impact.A lot of parents are struggling financially. It’s important they can go back to work.I trust the Government will tell usthings are not working and we need to make a change. It comes as the Institute for Fiscal Studies revealed that children from better-off households are spending an hour and a quarter more each day on education than poorer homes.But poorer families are less likely to want to send kids back to school.The Department for Education said: “We will do whatever we can to make sure no child, whatever their background, falls behind as a result of coronavirus. We have set out plans for a phasedof some year groups from June  at the earliest, in line with scientic advice.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dad shares pic girl kawasaki
story: A DAD has shared a devastating photo of his healthy five-year-old girl who is fighting for her le with Kawasaki disease. Piers Roberts says his family has been broken after his daughter Scarlett suddenly fell ill with the bug - just weeks after beating coronavirus.Scarlett suffered from a mild bout of Covid- five weeks ago which she recovered from, but is now in intensive care with a Kawasaki inflammatory response.Her dad said she was given just a  per cent chance of survival from the disease, which inflames blood vessels and is believed to be a reaction to coronavirus.He said Scarlett contracted Covid- in school before the lockdown, and described his daughter as fit and well six weeks before she suddenly suffered multi-organ failure.His aunt, June, also shared the heartbreaking picture of the five-year-old hooked up to a ventilator.She wrote on Twitter: This is my five-year-old great niece. She was fit and healthy until a mild bout of Covid- five weeks ago from which she appeared to recover.She is now in ICU with a Kawasaki inflammatory response.She is off the ventilator but has developed heart problems.It was revealed yesterday that an eight-month-old baby died from the coronavirus-linked Kawasaki disease, becoming the UK’s youngest known victim.Little Alexander Parsons died on April  from the rare childhood illness which inflames blood vessels.Medics have renamed the deadly condition as PIMS-TS, in the battle against Covid-.Englands health service had alerted at the end of April that cases of children in intensive care with a multi-system inflammatory state were rising.Children were displaying overlapping symptoms of severe COVID-, toxic shock syndrome and Kawasaki disease.The disease is also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.According to the NHS, the disease primarily affects children under five years of age.The blood vessels become swollen which can lead to complications in the coronary arteries .Kawasaki disease can cause aneurysms which can lead to a heart attack and heart disease.These the signs to look out for are:

title: one in three doctors off coronavirus
story: Of those who were not working,  per cent were confirmed infected and  per cent suspected.Many could have ed to work soonerthey had been tested as clear.But five per cent said they could not access a test for themselves, . per cent could not for their family and four per cent for patients.Some waited days for results, the poll of , members by the Royal College of Physicians found.Prof Andrew Goddard, president of the RCP, said: “It is no wonder that clinicians are worried for themselves and their families, when the very things that would keep them safe - PPE and testing - are still hard to access for so many of them.“We need to get those who have symptoms back to work as soon as possible so they need to be tested in good time - waiting three to four days for test results at a time like this is simply unacceptable.“Given that so many staff have had to take time off work during the pandemic, we welcome plans to roll out antibody tests to them as soon as possible so that we can understand whether they have or havent had the virus.“Employers must do more to help and reassure staff - giving them the confidence to fit-check their own PPE should be the bare minimum.“Clinicians are working incredibly hard in the most extraordinary circumstances the NHS has ever faced, but without the right safety measures in place, theyre still living in fear for their own health and the health of their families.“Confidence in the system they work in is low and more must be done to regain that trust.”To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: economy over worst scarring
story: THE economy is “over the worst” of the coronavirus crisis but could face permanent scarring, according to the head of the Office for Budget Responsibility.Robert Chote, chairman of the OBR said the level of “scarring” would depend on how business adapts to a new post Covid- world.He told the BBC’s Andrew Marr: “The key worry isyou have not just a very sharp downturn in the economy but one that scars its future potential.“But that should be the worst of it and we now go into a period of recovery as the restrictions are loosened. The key issues are how swt that recovery is and whether the economy is permanently scarred at the end of it.”The economist added: Were certainly going to see - temporarily - a higher amount of Government borrowing.The fact that the level of debt goes up on its own doesnt necessarily mean you have to have the sort of austerity that followed the financial crisis.”The economist revealed that he thought people’s behaviour would be critical factors to the nations recovery as well as how quickly lockdown restrictions are lted and said: If you allow people back into the workplace, back into shops, back into restaurants, will they actually go  Will they feel too nervous He added: Then also there will be political choices coming out of this. Do we want to spend a higher proportion of national income than we went in for example on health and social care All of these things together will shape the fiscal challenge for the Government coming out of this. A post financial crisis-style extended period of austerity is not a done deal.Separately, Carolyn Fairbairn, director-general of the Confederation of British Industry , told Sky News that businesses were thinking about protecting furloughed jobs for the future, adding it required a cautious, careful restart.She said: This week, I think from the business perspective, has been a week of glimmers of light at the end of the tunnel.We had the encouragement at the beginning of the week for businesses to get back to work, they are following that putting safety first... but what we are concerned about is the policies need to be coordinated across transport, across schools, across the devolved nations.If we do not have consensus that will undermine confidence amongst workers, consumers and people in general.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: get businesses open coronavirus
story: As the chief of the OBR made crystal-clear yesterday, the scarring will be permanent unless society can be ed to some semblance of normality as soon as is safely possible.Which means serious thought must now be given to getting businesses open:that involves masks in workplaces and Perspex separations in cafes and bars, so be it. It might feel strange at first, but we’ll get used to it.Militant unions telling teachers they should refuse to go back to work must also urgently rethink their stance.Reopening schools is obviously essentialwe are to prevent the poorest and most vulnerable children falling behind — new research reveals that better-off children are spending a whopping  per cent more time each day on education than those from poorer homes.But as parents can only go back to work once their kids are in class, it’s also the only way to kickstart the economy.Of course, there will always be an element of risk to getting society up and running again. Even before coronavirus, it would have been impossible for anyone to guarantee the safety of every worker every day.But the Government has stressed it’s “extremely unlikely” a school could be the source of a Covid- outbreak.And given the risks frontliners take every single day, that assurance should be good enough for teaching unions.WE welcome the news that the Government plans to push ahead with legislation to end free movement and replace it with a points-based immigration system before the end of this year.The new system is exactly what Brexit-voting Sun readers wanted: it will let us welcome the brightest and best — including doctors, nurses and carers — to the UK based on what they have to offer, not where they come from.And it’s logical to get it introduced quickly so businesses have time to prepare before the transition period ends.Let’s hope MPs have the sense to back the bill.WE can all sleep a little more soundly in our beds now the Government looks set to hit its target of recruiting , contact-tracers by the end of next week.It’s been obvious for a long time that widespread testing and tracing is the best way to contain the virus: all the countries that have fared best have been doing it from the start.But thanks to dodgy advice from Public Health England, Boris and his ministers gave up on it back in March.What a relief they’ve finally seen the light.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: government coronavirus lockdown rules region
story: THE government will not be ying coronavirus lockdown rules by region despite a wide range of infection rates across the country.Business Secretary Alok Sharma said the government would be sticking to a national approach at Downing Streets press briefing yesterday. Mr Sharma added that it was too soon to discuss a phased lting of lockdown by region.Dferent parts of the UK have a dferent R infection rate - which is used to indicate the speed the virus is spreading.According to experts from the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, the East Midlands have the fastest spread of infection with a rate of between . and ..London, which has been the hardest hit in the country has a R rate of . to . - the lowest in the country.Herefordshire, Norfolk, Durham and Cumberland now have  times as many cases as Devon, Cornwall and Dorset.Responding to a member of the public who asked whether the phased lting of lockdown would be better based on the virus reproduction R number regionally, Mr Sharma said it was too soon to take that approach.NHS England national medical director Stephen Powis added: There will be iations between dferent parts of the country, that occurs naturally in epidemics.We see that, for instance, in flu season each winter.Whats important going forward is increasingly we will be able to measure R direct.He added: We will have much better information of the directly measured R rate rather than R rate that is derived from models and other observations.That I think will give us a clearer picture of exactly how the infection is progressing in dferent parts of the country.George Batchelor, co-founder of Edge Health, a company that provides data analysis for the NHS, told the Sunday : As seen in countries like Singapore, the risk of a surge in new cases can happen even when the virus is under control.These surges, like the increase in cases in the North West of England, tend to be localised.If they are detected early, they can more easily be brought under some control. This requires a flexible regional response.This comes as drugs company AstraZeneca will make  million doses of the Oxford coronavirus vaccine by Septemberit works - and the UK will be the first to get it.During yesterdays conference, Mr Sharma announced a global licensing deal had been signed between Oxford University and the pharma firm as part of a £million plan to vaccinate half the UK population.The firm will make million doses of the vaccine over timeit proves to prevent the infection - and half of Brits would be in line to get one.In order to succeed as soon as possible, Mr Sharma announced a fresh £m in cash for the two universities to scale up production of their ground-breaking potential vaccines.£. million is earmarked for Oxford and £.million for Imperial.This will mean the UK will be the first country to get access to the Oxford vaccine, should it be successful.Oxford has finished its first phase of human trials this week - with everyone planned having received their vaccine doses on schedule.Imperial are on track to start their trial in June, with a second one by October.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: points based immigration system parliament
story: It will let the UK choose migrants according to their work skills and mark the end of the EU’s free movement.Ministers want it ready as soon as possible so firms can prepare for rule changes.Home Secretary Priti Patel said: “For the first time in decades, the UK will have the power to determine who comes to this country.”She added: “We know this will mean changes in the way businesses operate and recruit, but by doing this now we are giving businesses time to prepare and adapt as the economic recovery gathers pace.”Visas for workers and their families have been extended before the new laws to help fight the coronavirus crisis, and current EU citizens in the UK have also had their right to stay protected.Ms Patel added: “Our new points-based system is firmer, fairer, and simpler. It will attract the people we need to drive our economy forward and lay the foundation for a high wage, high skill, high productivity economy”The new immigration system will make it easier and quicker for medical professionals around the world to work in the NHS through a new fast-track NHS visa.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: primary school pupils urged in hoops
story: PARENTS have hit back at a primary school for saying children would have to stand inside hoops and fend for themselves in the playground when it reopens.Holywell Village First School , Northumberland, came under fire for its ridiculous set of social distancing ideas for when pupilsto classrooms on June .A now-deleted Facebook post seen bysaid pupils would be given play bubbles where they will have to stay when they go outside.A picture demonstrating how this would look showed hula hoops lined across the playground and marked with an X.It said toys, soft furnishings and books had been removed from classrooms while outside play equipment will not be able to be used as there is not enough staff to clean it afterwards.Parents also raised concern about strict rules regarding use of the toilet and children having to do their own first aidthey scrape themselves.The post said kids will be given specic time slots and will not be allowed to leave the classroom outside of their allocated toilet times.It said: If they fall over or have a toileting accident they will be encouraged to change themselves and clean their scrape or cut.We have sourced PPEwhich is for use only for staff protection should a child vomit, not for trips, falls or scrapes.If it is not possible for the child to clean themselves in the event of an accident, the parent will be called to collect them so they can do that at home.The school said it did not wish to make such drastic changes but that it was doing everything it can to adhere to government guidance to keep staff and children as safe as possible.The Facebook post, which was shared thousands of times, was deleted after parents hit back.People raised concern that no hot meals would be provided, that parents would be banned from entering the building and that children as young as four will have to learn more independently due to teachers having to keep a two-metre distance.One parent, Kristina Richards, , told : How on earth can children in reception and year one have an allocated toilet time  They are young kids andthey need to go to the toilet then they need to.No child aged   should have to clean up their own cuts. Andthey can’t do it then a parent will be called. Whatthat parent is now back to work Does that mean this child has to wait maybe an hour until a parent arrives to change their child’s soiled clothes or clean their bleeding legs  It’s ludicrous.In France, a recent picture showed nursery school children sitting alone in their own playground isolation sections.The picture, taken in the northern town of Tourcoing, on the Belgium border, shows a group of boys and girls being kept away from each other using areas marked out in chalk.Back in the UK, Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said yesterday that both primary and secondary school pupils couldto school in just two weeks time, with plans for students in Reception and Years , ,  and  to .He also sought to reassure parents concerned about pupils ing to school, insisting that the governments decision-making is based on the best scientic advice with children at the very heart of everything we do.

title: harry dunn mum britain stand up america
story: Charlotte Charles’s demand came as it em­erged the UK has agreed to extradite two fugitives to the US — which refuses to hand over crash suspect Anne Sacoolas, .She is charged with causing -year-old’s Harry’s death by dangerous driving outside a US military base in Northamptonshire last August.Sacoolas, the we of a US intelligence official, claimed diplomatic immunity and was able toto America.The US angrily rejected an extradition request.Ms Charles said no one should be extradited “until the US government agrees to play by the rules”.A spokesman acting on behalf of Mr Dunns parents added: Arrangements for sending wanted people across the Atlantic are hopelessly weighted in favour of the Americans.The Home Office confirmed extradition requests had been approved by Home Secretary Priti Patel for Jabir Motiwala, , and Colin Wilkinson, , from Hull, last month.Motiwala is wanted in the US to face charges of extortion, money laundering and conspiracy to import drugs while Wilkinson faces charges of downloading child sex abuse images in Texas, thereported.The pair are fighting the decisions and have appeals pending in the High Court. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. He told the BBC’s Andrew Marr: “It is absolutely safe,” then said the only way to be sure was to “stay at home” as there is “always, always... a risk”. Teaching unions fear it is unsafe for pupils and staff to go back to school on June . And Labour wants the test and trace system to be put in place before schools .Teachers demanded clarity on the safety of going back to school after Michael Gove plunged the Government’s lockdown exit strategy into further confusion.The Cabinet Office Minister initially promised teachers would be safe from Covid- as a phasedfor primary school kids starts on June . But seconds later he backtracked – admitting the only way to completely avoid infection was to stay at home. The standoff between the Government and teaching unions intensied as Hartlepool council in Co Durham joined Liverpool in saying its schools will remain shut as cases locally continue to increase. Labour and teaching unions insist a testing and tracking system should be a precondition for schools reopening, so that inidual outbreaks can be controlled. But testing again fell below the , daily target, with , tests carried out or dispatched in the  hours to am on Sunday. It came as sunseekers flocked to beaches over the weekend after a partial loosening of lockdown restrictions, despite the UK death toll rising by  to , on Sunday. Beaches including Southend in Essex were packed, cars crammed into a car park at Durdle Door, Dorset, and hundreds of bikers were among visitors to Matlock Bath, Derbys. The rush came despite pleas not to flock to hotspots after the “stay local” rule was lted in England. Asked about teachers’ safety, Mr Gove told BBC’s The Andrew Marr Show: “Yes, teachers will be safe in schools... “Some of the best leaders in current education have said that it is absolutely safe for children to , absolutely safe for teachers and other staff toas well.”  But askedhe could guarantee no teacher would be infected as a result of ing to the classroom, he said: “The only way ever to ensure that you never catch coronavirus is to stay at home completely.There is always, in any loosening of these restrictions, a risk of people catching coronavirus. You can never eliminate risk, but... it’s extremely unlikely any school is likely to be the source of a Covid outbreak, andfor any reason there are risks we can take steps to mitigate them.” Teachers’ unions have said they will provide health and safety guidance for their members so they can saythey feel it is too dangerous to work. But Mr Gove said: “The clear scientic and clinical advice is that it is safe to have schools reopen accompanied with social distancing. Children only have one chance at education. Over the last decade we have made signicant strides in closing the gap between the richest and poorest in our schools. This lockdown has put that at risk.” He said the Government was on track to meet its target of , contact tracers by next week, with , now recruited. But last week, Northern Ireland Secretary Brandon Lewis said just , had signed up. Hartlepool leaders said: “Given that coronavirus cases locally continue to rise, Hartlepool borough council has been working with schools and we have agreed they will not reopen on Monday st June. Whilst we recognise the importance of schools reopening, we will be taking a measured and cautious approach.” Liverpool has confirmed that its schools will only be open to vulnerable pupils and the children of key workers on June . Sunderland City Council leader Graeme Miller described the lockdown changes as “nonsense”. Manchester mayor Andy Burnham warned: “”Nervousness in the north about the R number will see more councils adopt their own approach on schools, as Liverpool, Gateshead and Hartlepool are doing.”

title: pubs could start selling food
story: NewsPubs could start selling food and drink from street stalls within weeksThe government is looking at making clear pubs, cafes or restaurants can set up market stalls - but theres no sign beer gardens will reopenShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsPunters queuing outside a Liverpool pub which has already started selling takeaway lockdown pints " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe government is poised to let Englandaposs pubs and restaurants sell food and drink from street stalls. Sources confirmed ministers are looking at letting firms set up aposmarket-styleapos stalls for takeaways within weeks. There is a big condition, though - these firms must have a licence for tables and chairs at the front of their premises. The plan, which is still being considered, could let some pubs creak slowly back into le before they can actually open their doors. Existing plans say pubs, cafes and restaurants could start to reopen from July, but only limited open-air dining areas would be included in this first wave. Sources have made clear pubs have next to no chance of reopening fully in July, and may not even open in July at all. So according to the Sunday , Local Government Secretary Robert Jenrick will issue guidance to give pubs a tiny bit more freedom.The guidance will reportedly say shops, restaurants and pubs can set up stalls out front - but only in areas where they already have a licence to place tables and chairs. A Whitehall source said it could lead to a more vibrant style of continental town centres in the summer. Pubs, cafes and restaurants are already able to run as takeaways during the pandemic. And separately, outdoor market stalls that sell food are already allowed to carry on running. However, these two dferent rules have not been formally combined until now. But those hoping for aof beer gardens will be left disappointed.  There is still no sign that any seating areas of any kind, even outdoors, will reopen at all before July. Instead, people might be expected to take their food or drink and move away to a public open space like a park, where they are allowed to sit down. People must still stay two metres apart and gatherings of more than two are banned unless youaposre from the same household. If two people from dferent households meet, they must sit two metres apart.It seems likely any guidance would only apply to England, because Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland have all set out their own lockdown easing plans. It comes despite pubs and trade bodies calling on the Government to go further and let them open beer gardens, as long as tables are spread out. Peter Borg-Neal, founder of Oakman Inns, told the Mirror last week: “We could use free standing screens to separate tables, or use a natural gap of two metres, have staggered bookings, contactless payments and handwash stations. “Simple common sense, carefully applied with trained staff should work.” Pub, cafe and restaurants will only begin after England enters step three of easing the lockdown. Step one happened in the last week, and involved being able to exercise unlimited times per day and sit still in an open space.

title: save free tv licences 20th
story: NewsSave free TV licences on their th anniversary, campaigners urge GovernmentEXCLUSIVE: Labour peer George Foulkes said two decades on from the policy coming into effect, over-s still deserve the lelineShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  MAY News" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Labour peer Lord George Foulkes, who was a minister when the benefit was introduced in November , urged the Tories to honour a pledge to protect free licences.He said: “This year we will mark the th anniversary of the introduction of the concessionary TV licence for over-s. “We should be celebrating how this progressive Labour policy has helped reduce pensioner poverty and combat loneliness. “It should not be the year we mark its end.”  The Conservatives pledged at the  election to protect free licences for the rest of that Parliament, which was due to run until . But the BBC had already been handed responsibility for funding the leline from June , under a deal agreed in . The corporation is restricting eligibility to OAPs who receive Pension Credit. It says keeping licences free for all over-s would cost £million by -. Some . million pensioner households must fork out £. a year from August .Curbs were due to come into effect on June  but were delayed for two months because of the coronavirus outbreak.Writing exclusively for the Mirror, Lord Foulkes, , urged ministers to save the benefit.  He says: “If they have any compassion at all, they should now honour their manesto promise and keep the concession indefinitely – not just because it makes sense but, as the Conservatives put it themselves, to promise our over-s aposthe security and dignity they deserveapos.” He will tackle the Government over free licences in the House of Lords on June . Age UK charity director Caroline Abrahams said: “To start charging the over-s now on the th anniversary of free TV licences would be an insult to all those older people who are already struggling with the loneliness and isolation that this lockdown is creating and will continue to do for months to come, as well as having to dig deep to find the finances to pay for it.”  Bectu broadcasting union chief Philippa Childs said: “The -year anniversary of free licence fees for the over-s is a landmark that we should, as a nation, be celebrating. “Instead the Conservative Government has forced the BBC to take on this cost, abdicating its responsibility for what is essentially a welfare benefit. “The Government must take back responsibility for funding free licences for all over-s.” The Silver Voices campaign group highlighted tributes offered to war veterans last weekend as the Government marked the th anniversary of VE Day. Pointing out over-s were alive at the end of the war, director Dennis Reed said: “For  years they have had the right to free TV licences in recognition of their long contributions to society and the low level of the state pension. “The VE Day generation need the threat of losing their free licence on August  like a kick in the teeth.

Business Secretary Alok Sharma told the public that the country is moving toward level three on the five-tier Covid alert system - which would see some of the strictest measures reduced. Since the lockdown was put in place on March , it has been in level four - meaning the threat is classed as severe. Level three means it is classed as substantial. But Mr Sharma warned that bringing the country back to normal must be done in careful steps in order to avoid a second peak of cases. He said at todayaposs daily Downing Street briefing - in which he confirmed that the Covid- death toll has risen by a further  - that progress was being made. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, read our liveblog here Describing five threat levels - with five being the most severe and one being the least - he stated: “Throughout the period of lockdown we have been at level four. “Thanks to you, people across the country, we have collectively helped to bring the R level down. “We are now in a position to begin moving to level , in careful steps.” And he continued: “‘We have set out the first of three steps we will take to carefully mody the measures, gradually ease the restrictions and begin to allow people toto their usual way of le while avoiding a disastrous second peak that overwhelms the NHS.”  The Business Secretary said the UK would move to level three “when it is safe to do so”. The five tier aposCovid Alert Systemapos will be used to determine when it is safe for measures to be relaxed, and for le to gradually get back to normal. There are five tiers to the Covid Alert System. Level Five: Critical  - The virus is spreading rapidly and the NHS is overwhelmed. A tight lockdown is required.Level Four - Severe  - The NHS is stretched but coping. There is still community transmission of the disease . Level Three - Substantial-  The disease is in general circulation and the NHS is operating at extra capacity. Restrictions remain on the public sector and normal le.Level Two - Moderate  - There is low transmission of the disease, and the NHS is operating normally. Schools and businesses can open, with some special measures still in place.Level One - Low  - The disease is no longer present in the UK. Public and private sectors can operate normally.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTheir friends will look the same, their teachersapos faces familiar and their lessons will continue - but Britain’s primary pupils face an alien landscape when theyto the classroom. The artwork that once adorned the walls will have been torn down, their desks spaced two metres apart and toys, Lego blocks and even old fashioned counting beads will have disappeared. Lunchtimes will be spent at desks, outside play equipment cordoned off, toilet times will be scheduled and contact with teachers so limited that they won’t even be able to put a plaster on a child who falls over. This will be the sterile reality of le in the UK’s , primaries when they open in June. And teachers fear it will have a huge emotional impact on kids.  One East Yorkshire teacher said: “We are worried how this will affect children’s mental health and also educational outcomes. “I’m concerned that parents are not being made aware of what education will look like and that their child’s experience will be far from normal. “Children have already undergone a lot of disruption and, at a time when we wish we couldto our normal routines in order to reassure them, I fear this will only unsettle them further.” Health Secretary Gavin Williamson has left it to inidual schools to have “flexibility” to follow Government guidelines, which mirror the approach of schools in Denmark which started a phasedin April. Head teachers now face the headache of making their schools safe for reception and Year One and Six primary classes and in just two weeks. The guidelines suggest schools introduce one-way systems for kids, ide corridors to keep them apart and stagger breaks as well as arrival and home times so parents don’t congregate. It’s also advised youngsters are placed into small gangs of friends who will not be allowed to mix with other sets or dferent years. Constant hand-washing will be in place when kids arrive, come in from play and before and after eating. The guidelines state: “Consider how to encourage young children to learn and practice these habits through games, songs and repetition.” One head teacher this week took the unusual move of spelling out the changes to parents on her school website, writing: “Some of the parents who want their child tohave stated this is for their mental health and well-being. “This worries me more as I do feel some of the measures I will have to take will completely work against this.”  In a list of changes, headed ‘The Truths’, headteacher Marianne Allan, of Cambois Primary School in Blyth, Northumberland, told parents that all unnecessary furniture and equipment will be removed, teachers will not be allowed to sit beside pupils who need help and lunches will be eaten in classrooms. Ms Allan said children who fall over or have a toilet accident will be encouraged to change themselves or clean their scrape or cut. Otherwise parents will have to collect them. In a poignant message she wrote: “Today I looked at a memory on my phone. It was from a year ago today when some girls in year  and  made me the most beautul table for my lunch, it was covered in lip gloss to smell nice and full of sparkle and jewels. “This is the school I miss. These are the activities we hope to resume. “This will NOT be possible in June. This is the school we want to see back, where children run up and hug their teachers and friends. The school children can walk safely around a building without measures or go to the toilet without supervision and for them to be cleaned afterwards.”  The Government has prioritised reception and Year one learners because they are learning “basic essentials” and Year Six so they can prepare for the move to High School. In Secondaries, Year  and  will get some “face-to-face” time with teachers. But one primary teacher in Bridlington said: “The classrooms will be striped bare of any joy. “Art work will be banned from the wall, resources like counting bricks and beads will be banned to stop the spread of the virus. “Our school has made the decision not to mark exercise books for  hours just to be safe. “it’s so sad because there will be no toys for the little ones in reception and we won’t even be able to help them take bottle lids off their juicethey struggle. “I don’t say this to make parents feel guilty because I know some have no choice but to send their children, but they have a right to know what the reality will be.”

title: anne diamond disgruntled meghan make
story: NewsopinionAnne Diamond: Disgruntled Meghan will make a mint from her diary on royal leMeghan Markle kept a personal diary all the time she lived in Britain documenting her engagement to Prince Harry, the wedding and beyond which will be published as a bombshell memoirShareCommentsByAnne Diamond:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsopinionMeghan Markle and husband Harry are already releasing a book on royal le " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. It’s been revealed that she kept a diary all the time she lived in Britain, covering everything from her engagement to Harry, the wedding and beyond. Well,any of us wondered how the Sussexes would finance their new le together “out of the limelight” in Los Angeles, we need wonder no more. A diary, even a tame one, would make a bombshell memoir and a prize beyond price for both Meghan and any publisher brave enough to bid for the rights. And we’d all be daft enough to buy it. We’re already pre-ordering the book we KNOW she’s been ­controlling. It’s called Finding Freedom: Harry and Meghan and the Making of a Modern Royal Family, and it’s due out in August. If the very title ­annoys you like it does me then you can only imagine what self-serving conceit lurks inside. How, only two years married, can they claim to understand the making of a modern Royal Family  Especially since they’ve turned their back on royalty  Meghan says she hopes it will “finally set the record straight and show the world why they were left with no other choice than to leave the royal le”. She also apparently believes “readers will finally understand the monumental anguish and turmoil she had to endure with a stf upper lip” and “see her ­vulnerable side, something the book does in great detail”.  We may be curious, even scornful, but she’ll be laughing all the way to the bank. As for the diary, we don’t knowshe’s even thinking of making it public – but what a nest egg, should she ever need it. I can’t help but wonderHarry knew his lovely bride was sitting down to chronicle her thoughts as the royals flailed around in their futile attempts to welcome her and make her happy. In my day, women were ­encouragedto build themselves a ‘F*** Off Fund’, should their relationships go bad. The idea was to keep it a secret from your ­husband or boyfriend sothings ever went south, you could flee in a ­flurry of independence and set up on your own.

Wild cat sightings have been claimed across the British countryside, with numerous alleged sightings in rural Devon and Cornwall. Their existence in the wild here in the UK is still a much debated topic. Plenty of people believe we have enough evidence to suggest they do exist. Brett Bennett recently took photos of huge, four-clawed cat paw prints pretty close to where the black cat was supposedly seen, in Holbeam Wood in Newton Abbott. Brett said: These woods arenapost used very much at the moment due to lockdown, and itaposs only about a five-mile walk from here to Dartmoor, so when I saw the prints it made me think. I sent the photos to my partner, and she said that there had been sightings around this area before. Brett said heaposs recently been finding more animal remains, like deer legs, during walks with his dog, Kalba. Rumours of big cats on the moors of Devon and Cornwall have been around for a long time, often referred to as the Beast of Bodmin, Exmoor or Dartmoor. This theory, made public in July last year, mainly comes from Benjamin Mee, owner of Dartmoor Zoo, revealing three pumas were due to arrive their nearly  years ago, but instead were supposedly released into the wild by circus entertainer and former Plymouth Zoo owner, Mary Chipperfield. Mr Mee said Dartmoor Zoo was expecting a delivery of five pumas after Plymouth Zoo was forced to close down in . Rather than surrender them to another zoo, Ms Chipperfield is thought to have released her favourite breeding pair into the wild, plus a young male to keep them company. Thereaposs been loads of alleged sightings of the animals over the years in Devon and Cornwall. Initially it was rumoured to be prowling across Bodmin Moor, and was called the Beast of Bodmin. The mysterious creature is described as a phantom wild cat, possibly with two sharp prominent teeth like those found on a leopard. It was first spotted in  and ever since reports of the Beast of Bodmin have flooded in. Since , more than  sightings have been reported in the Devon and Cornwall force area. Information supplied following a Freedom of InformationAct request show that officers were called on  separate occasions between January  and July . On at least four occasions officers attended but took no further action to investigate.

The Mirror is building on this by connecting people for unique online conversations – it’s a chance to meet someone dferent, find out what others are going through and even help people feel less lonely. Before the coronavirus crisis, Joan Pons Laplana and Thomas Webb might never have met. Joan, originally from Barcelona, is a senior charge nurse at a busy ­intensive care unit in Sheffield. Thomas, Norfolk born and bred, is a supermarket checkout worker. Joan, , is an outgoing father-of-three who is passionate about the NHS and Spanish music.  Thomas, , is a self-described introvert who is into his girlfriend, video games and a drop of cider. But this pandemic has changed who matters in our country. Now, in May , Thomas and Joan are both key workers keeping Britain fed and alive – two of the heroes we all clap for on our ­doorsteps on Thursday nights. For our ground-breaking Britain Connects project, we asked Joan and Thomas to meet up via a videocall and chat about their experiences. The result was a fascinating conversation that touched on love, loneliness, le, death and everything in between. “As you can see from my accent it’s not a Yorkshire accent, I’m Spanish,” says Joan, introducing himself. “I’ve been here for  years, working in the NHS. I’m a nurse. I’m working tonight in intensive care.” Thomas, from Great Yarmouth, smiles. “I work in the local ­supermarket, I’ve lived here most of my le, I’ve got a typical Norfolk accent, I guess,” he says. “According to the Government we’ve gone from being low-skilled workers to key workers,” Joan says. Thomas modestly says his job just isn’t as important as Joan’s. They chat about protective equipment. Joan feels like Robocop in PPE – it takes him  minutes to put on. Thomas says he uses endless hand sanitiser, and that Asda has introduced measures such as screens and one-way systems to keep staff safe. Out and about though, he doesn’t use a mask because he wants there to be enough for people like Joan.Joan speaks eloquently about how he’s felt since Brexit.“In the past few years, people very quickly wanted to know where I came from,” he says. “That has disappeared, now people are not bothered where I come from, they’re just happy to see me and happy that I’m a nurse. “That feeling of belonging has come back because in the past few years, as a non-British national, I felt a bit ‘not wanted’ from the Government and part of society. “In a way, we’ve come back to when I came here years ago. It doesn’t matter where you come from. I hope that this feeling will carry on after.” Thomas looks serious. “It shouldn’t matter where you come from. You’re more than welcome. You call the UK your home.”Thomas has kept apart from his girlfriend Paris in lockdown – to protect her and her parents from the risks his job brings. But they work together at Asda, making it hard. Joan is amazed by Thomas’s resolve in not being tempted to see a loved one. “I would be,” admits Joan. “We’re human. My kids don’t live with me and I’m finding that very hard. “My -year-old... I haven’t seen him for over four weeks. “He’s just had his th birthday over Zoom. But as soon as he turns  you can’t see your kid, because they’re adults. One day I’m allowed to see him, the following day I’m not...” Thomas agrees. “It’s been lonely,” he says. “I work with my partner on a few of my shts and it’s very tempting just to go over there but I can’t because I’ve got to do my job. It’s lonely but she does her best to make sure I’m not by Facetiming as much as she can.” He is worried because his mental health hasn’t been great in the past. “I look at my front door and feel like I can’t open that, I’m locked in,” he says. “I go to work, interact a bit. The four, now known as the Lions of Lyon, were just a few months old when they were rescued by French wildle charity, Fondation  Million d’Amis. Dadou was found on Paris’s most famous street – the Champs-Elysees – in the back of a Lamborghini missing the tip of his tail after his owner was caught by police officers taking photos with the cub.  Horus, the largest of the four cubs, was found on a child’s bed in an apartment on the outskirts of Paris while his owner was hiding in his neighbour’s cupboard. Police were alerted after images of the cub had been posted on Snapchat. Cersei was found on the same day as Horus in a garage in Marseille and was suffering from a catalogue of illnesses. As well as being very underweight, she also had skin irritation, a dull coat, gastrointestinal problems and corneal ulcers. Thea, the smallest and youngest of the cubs, was surrendered by her owner. She had glaucoma, and was under-developed and underweight, with extreme hair loss and diarrhoea.

This is consistent with data from international studies showing low rates of disease in children and suggesting limited spread among children and from children to adults#xD.:Network Rail says it will introduce , more trains a day to avoid overcrowdingBritain#xs rail network started running more services on Monday, raising concerns that more people will start to use trains which could lead to crowding at stations and onboard amid the novel coronavirus outbreak. Researchers at the Oxford Vaccine Group began testing the vaccine candidate ChAdOx nCoV- in humans on April  to see whether it can protect healthy people from Covid-. The programme will allow researchers to assess the safety of the candidate, and its ability to generate an immune response. - How does the study work  Up to , participants have been recruited across multiple study sites in Oxford, Southampton, London and Bristol. They must also be in good health, not be pregnant or breastfeeding, and must not have previously taken part in a trial with an adenoviral vaccine or received any other coronavirus vaccines. - How will the trial work  The dose used in the trial was chosen based on previous experiences with other ChAdOx based vaccines. If transmission remains high, enough data may be available in a couple of months buttransmission levels drop, this could take up to six months. - What is the vaccine  ChAdOx nCoV- is made from ChAdOx, which is a weakened version of a common cold virusthat causes infections in chimpanzees. It has been genetically changed so it is impossible for it to grow in humans. Researchers hope their version will make the body recognise and develop an immune response to the spike protein - recognisable in images of the virus - that will help stop Covid- from entering human cells and therefore prevent infection. Cricket sort of has to be on the back burner while every thing  gets better.#xCAs much as we would love to play sport and want sport back, I think it has to be about the nation and getting things back together and making sure people#xs safety and key workers and the NHSare looked after.#xDThe United Kingdom has over , confirmed cases of the coronavirus so far and it leads Europe with nearly , deaths.Social distancing protocols will prevent fans from attending matches at stadiums and Wood said their absence will be felt by the players who consider them like the th man. #xCBeing a fast bowler, I would go to fine leg on the boundary edge and you are right next to the crowd there and they can give you a bit of motivation or inspiration,#xD Wood said.#xCThey can make you feel like there is an extra guy in our side. Parents, as well as teachers and the public at large, need to be able to assess whether it is safe for pupils and staff to . The British Medical Association, the doctors’ trade union, fears it is too early and an admission by Cabinet Minister Michael Gove, an ex-Education Secretary, that he couldn’t ­guarantee they would all be safe is worrying. Resuming lessons is important for children, particularly those from disadvantaged families who may struggle to catch upthey fall behind. Yet the suspicion next month’s timetable was a political goal isn’t allayed by the baiting of teachers who are understandably concerned. Unless foolproof ways of preventing the spread of coronavirus are devised, teachers are entitled to inform gung-ho Education ­Secretary Gavin Williamson to think again.  End TV drama If Boris Johnson wants to start rebuilding trust in his Government, let him honour a previous election ­manesto promise to retain free TV licences for the over-s instead of passing the buck to the BBC. The appeal by Age UK recognises the telly is a reliable friend for our elderly, the only one allowed into homes during lockdown. In a year we celebrated the th anniversary of VE Day, has the Prime Minister thought what a cruel reward it would be to start charging the wartime generation £. to watch the box  If he hasn’t, he should. story: NewsWoman shares honest truth about why shes decided not to shave during lockdownElise Britten from Somerset says her reason for not de-hairing in lockdown is not because she cant buy a razor or she wants to make a feminist statementShareCommentsByLucy Skoulding:,  MAY NewsElise says the reason isnt because she cant buy a razor " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A woman has shared the honest truth about how she hasnapost shaved since the beginning of lockdown - all so she can spread an important message.Journalist Elise Britten said her lack of shaving isnapost because she canapost buy a razor or because she likes the way it looks or she wants to make a feminist statement. Although full respect to those who choose to, she added.Instead, Elise hasnapost shaved for the last couple of months simply because it hasnapost made the top of [her] to-do list, she said, writing about her experience for Somerset Live.She explained the task is in the back of her mind as something she will eventually do when she has a spare spot. But Iaposve been busy, she said, really busy. While many people have expressed how bored theyaposve been during lockdown Elise has said sheaposs working harder than ever and is certainly not sitting around with nothing to do. She explained: There’s lots of stories about how to fill time during lockdown boredom – but there’s plenty of us out there who are working harder than ever. I don’t just mean the healthcare heroes on the frontline, who have rightly been the focus of any mention of work still going on. There’s plenty of us who are working less noble – but still very demanding jobs. Elise went on to explain that, at her new site, a number of employees have been furloughed but sheaposs still working and thereaposs a lot to be done. I’ve also been working hard to prepare for my senior journalism qualications, spending hours of my own time on that each day, she added. Concerned about the usual exercise she gets running for trains and in her regular netball training sessions, Elise added that sheaposs also followed a workout routine during lockdown. She said: So I’ve come up with a full-on daily exercise checklist– looking to take long walks, - minute hard cardio workout videos and - minute dance videos each day. Most days I do it, but it takes way longer than my non-lockdown routine would take. Elise went on to point out that she doesnapost necessarily think sheaposs shedding any pounds but that sheaposs doing the exercise more because it makes her feel better. It gives me structure and purpose and clears my head, she said. So why specically has Elise struggled to find the time for a quick shave  Because she doesnapost actually shave. Sheaposs never done it in her le. She explained: My headline isn’t entirely accurate. I’ve never actually shaved . You will have to forgive me because ‘de-hairing’ as I would accurately call it would have confused you. Usually Elise uses a combination of hot wax strips and hair removal cream so she can avoid having to shave every day and that horrible prickly feeling you get in between shaves. The only downside to her method is that it takes her around and hour to do it properly. So itaposs much more of a commitment than a quick shave in the shower. Elise continued, saying that usually events in her le will spur her on to de-hair as she puts it. That could be anything from a party or an important, face-to-face work meeting. Of course, there’s none of that at the moment during lockdown, she pointed out. Honestly it’s not just de-hairing – it’s all vanity really. Elise admitted she has felt a bit self-conscious about it all at times. She said: When I’ve been out for my walks in a sleeveless top or dress and it’s crossed my mind – I have tried to consciously keep my arms down to hide my hair .

Referring to the imagesapos popularity online, Father Pelc said: I’m not objecting to it, this whole idea of combating evil is a good one. We all want to believe that the devil is not the most powerful force on the earth and neither is COVID-. Father Pelc went on to tell TODAY while his water pistol ploy was light hearted, the people of Detroit are taking lockdown very seriously.  He said his parish could be re-opened next Sunday for public masses but the feeling he has from people is itaposs too early. People are saying they don’t want to come out just yet. There’s still a lot of fear out there and I don’t blame them. In the meantime, the parish has been making use of livestreams and pre-recorded services, with up to three masses worth tuning in.

title: dundee fc foreign legion scottish steel barry smith
story: Dundee legend Barry Smith has lted the lid on how he adapted to the Bonettis’ “off-the-cuff” approach to le at Dens Park.It’s  years since the managerial duo of enigmatic brothers, Ivano and Dario, arrived to take charge at the Dark Blues.Having played under some of the biggest names at the biggest Italian clubs, challenging for league titles and European trophies, the pair arrived with a burgeoning contacts book and plenty of ambition.An influx of foreign players followed, with Claudio Caniggia, Juan Sara, Fabian Caballero, Marco de Marchi and Georgi Nemsadze arriving in the first year.The second saw the likes of Temuri Ketsbaia, Julian Speroni and Fan Zhiyi come in.The excess that funded all of these big names eventually caught up with the club as they failed to sell them on and administration beckoned a year after the Bonettis departed.Prior to their appointment, the Dark Blues had enjoyed a positive campaign under Jocky Scott.But huge changes lay ahead and former club captain and manager Smith knew he had two options – leave or get with the programme.He said: “There was probably a mix of anticipation and trepidation among the players, we really just didn’t know what to expect.“We had a good squad when they came in, we had finished a point off fth under Jocky Scott but the first day back in pre-season there were a few new faces around.“I always said thatyou think your face doesn’t fit then it’s up to you to make it fit. My plan was to work as hard as I could to be part of the team.“If they wanted things done a certain way then I was going to do that to the best of my ability thenit doesn’t work out, I’ve done all I can.“There were big changes to training but going away for three weeks in pre-season to Italy was a big one. Usually you’d only be away for a week but this was a long time.“They did lay everything that was to happen out in front of you, though. However, there was a strict menu on offer –you didn’t like it, you’d go hungry.”Training too was completely dferent as Dundee adopted a football strategy that had served the Bonetti brothers in their homeland.As a future coach and boss, Smith says he learned a lot during their time in the City of Discovery, evensome elements of their approach were dficult to get to grips with.“The way they structured training was completely dferent as well but dferent managers all have dferent views,” he added.“Training would change time but we’d train every day and there were a few double sessions.“They relied on doing the same thing rigidly over and over so you knew what you were getting and there was very little change.“I have to say I learned a lot about working on shape and positional play. Previous managers had done shape but not to the extent the Bonettis worked on it.“Training could be a bit off-the-cuff sometimes. They were obviously new to coaching themselves and learning as they went.”There were high-profile disagreements as foreign signings kept Scottish players out of the starting XI.The Bonetti brothers’ volatile nature also led to fall outs behind the scenes, but Smith focused on working hard in training and reaping the rewards.“I always treat people as they treat me and the Bonettis treated me very well,” he said.“I’m not saying they did that with every player – there were definitely a few not treated as well as they should have been.“I played with players I never expected to line up alongside at Dundee. Georgi Nemsadze was wonderful, Claudio Caniggia was a top talent, but they also needed the Scottish guys like myself, Gav Rae, Steven Tweed and Willie Falconer to make the core of the team.“I don’t think the foreign guys really understood Scottish football or knew what to expect.“We all just got our heads down and knuckled down to work. I think the Bonettis appreciated that.“They were good times and I’m sure the fans wouldn’t change seeing those players in dark blue even with what happened afterwards in administration.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: dundee fc john nelms spfl
story: The result of Tuesday’s failed SPFL inquiry vote has vindicated Dundee managing director John Nelms, according to a Dark Blues fan chief.Following weeks of back-biting and sniping over the Dens Park supremo’s now infamous voting U-turn at the start of April, two thirds of league clubs voted against an independent inquiry.With nine out of  Championship clubs voting ‘no’, chairman of the Dundee Supporters# Association, Kenny Ross, believes a “clear statement” has been made in relation to Nelms# actions.And Ross also insists the response from Dundee fans at large has been one of acceptance.He told the Tele: “The club seem quite relaxed about what’s been going on the past couple of weeks, not saying anything.“John Nelms doesn’t say much at the best of times but I think that relaxed attitude is echoed by the fans.“With nine out of  Championship clubs voting no, there is also a clear statement there and I think it vindicates John Nelms.“Personally, I would have liked an inquiry because there are questions that need answered but it was pretty overwhelming from Dundee’s fellow Championship clubs and % of all the clubs that it wasn’t wanted.“It’s clear from that there isn’t really a problem from most clubs on the U-turn – the majority wanted it with over % voting that way and the Deloitte inquiry said there was no wrongdoing.“With reconstruction talks ending, fans do wonder what John Nelms achieved through the U-turn but I think we are all past it now. I’ve not had anyone on to me about it all, there’s very little online about this week’s vote – I don’t think anyone really cares now.”Rangers vehemently led the call for a vote on an independent inquiry into the SPFL’s conduct during the coronavirus shutdown, as well as Dundee’s actions in changing their vote.That led to Gers fans bombarding online posts from the club and DSA social media, but Ross believes the reaction from fellow Dundee supporters is telling.He added: “Anytime the DSA are posting stuff on social media, we have to go through and delete loads of stuff.“It’s almost amusing now – Dundee fans responding generally laugh at them. Dundee have been getting hammered but they are not rising to it all and that, I think, shows the general feeling of the support.“It is bizarre because Dundee’s vote hasn’t affected Rangers really – our club has been affected more because there’s now no play-offs.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: revealed dario bonetti kicked rugby park
story: The Bonetti era at Dundee didn’t throw up many dull moments – and Kilmarnock fans will certainly remember the night assistant Dario entertained them in the stands at Rugby Park.A combination of a car accident, a paperwork error and Bonetti missing a Killie goal saw Ayrshire fans that night experience both sides of the charismatic and, at times, volatile Italian.With no place on the bench for Dark Blues assistant manager, Dario watched the game from the press box behind the home supporters in the main stand.The Evening ’s former senior football writer, Tom Duthie, had a front-row seat to the spectacle.He said: “Most of the squad had travelled the night before the game, but Dario Bonetti was heading west on the Saturday.“Unfortunately an accident blocked the main road between Glasgow and Kilmarnock and along with most fans, and press, Dario did not arrive at Rugby Park in time for kick off.“When he got there he found his name had not been included on the official list of those in the Dundee technical area and, for once, the assistant manager had to head for the stand to observe the action.“Along with full-back Marcello Marrocco, who was injured, he decided to join us in the press box at the back of the main stand.“Given that the stand is for home fans, it crossed my mind this could lead to problems because I knew there was no way the passionate Italian would stay quiet. He didn#t.“But as well as kicking every ball for his team, big Dario also engaged with the punters sitting nearby and gave them what must have been one of their most entertaining match experiences ever.“Unfortunately for Dario his late arrival meant he missed an opening goal for Killie and although Dundee equalised before the break he was still unaware of it as he headed for the dressing-room at half-time.“There were some confused players in there as he blasted them and told them they were lucky to be ahead.“When he repeated that opinion on retaking his seat for the second-half I can remember a couple of awkward minutes as Marrocco, Dundee#s press officer Niall Scott and I discussed who should be the one to tell him the correct score.“I escaped that dangerous task by pointing out I was not a club employee and they were.“If memory serves me, it was Marrocco who broke the news, to be met with an eruption from his assistant gaffer.“I should add that outside of game time, Dario was as charming as his brother.“In their first season together the pair steered Dundee to a top six finish and produced a team capable of playing football that was as pleasing on the eye as anything theof the country.“As their second season progressed, however, Ivano was making increasingly frequent trips back to Italy and it was clear all was not well behind the scenes.“It came as no surprise when he was replaced by Jim Duffy in the summer of  and in just over another year the extent of the club#s spending during the Bonetti experiment became clear as it plunged into administration and was on the brink of extinction.“For all that, Dundee fans understandably remember those two years with great fondness, as do press men like myself who experienced a time the like of which is highly unlikely to be seen again.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.
