story: BALLYNAHINCH Youthrsquos annual award winners have been announced. Unfortunately, there wasnrsquot a presentation event owing to the current lockdown.However, each prizewinner received a letter from club chairperson Hannah Majury and will be presented with a trophy at a later date.The Green Card Award, the most prestigious award at the club, which goes to the player who embodies the ethos of the club, was won by Edan Reid from the U- squad.Mini soccer prize winners: Sportsperson of the Year, Charlie Adams Most Improved Player of the Year, Daniel Scott, Managerrsquos Player of the Year, Thomas Spratt.U- prize winners: Sportsperson of the Year, Toby Jackson Most Improved Player of the Year, Jacob Munyangaju Managerrsquos Player of the Year, Alex Herron.U- prize winners: Sportsperson of the Year, Sam Crawford and Luke Harkin Most Improved Player of the Year, Jake Gilmour Managerrsquos Player of the Year, Blake Kelly.U- yellow section prize winners: Sportsperson of the Year, Emma Owens Most Improved Player of the Year, Jack Wright Managerrsquos Player of the Year, Cole Gunda.U- black section prize winners: Sportsperson of the Year, Max Blakley Most Improved Player of the Year, Jim Mooney Managerrsquos Player of the Year, Toby Brashaw.U- prize winners: Sportsperson of the Year, Toby Lyons Most Improved Player of the Year, Aaron Jackson Top Goalscorer of the Year, Oskar Campbell Playersrsquo Player of the Year, Charlie Parkinson Managerrsquos Player of the Year, Curtis Johnston.U- prize winners: Sportsperson of the Year, Stella Keers Most Improved Player of the Year, Conn OrsquoHagan Top Goalscorer of the Year, Daniel Walsh Playerrsquos Player of the Year, Justin Herbert and Josh Annett Managerrsquos Player of the Year, Dawson Kelly.U- prize winners: Sportsperson of the Year, Kian Connolly Most Improved Player of the Year, Adam McCaughtry Top Goalscorer of the Year, Liam Burns Playersrsquo Player of the Year, Liam Burns Managerrsquos Player of the Year, Ryan Murphy..prettyPhoto

title: Castlewellan author Ciaran’s book helps to understand grief
story: A BOOK penned by a Castlewellan man that helps children understand grief has seen an upturn in sales during the coronavirus pandemic.Thirty eight year-old Ciaran Milligan, who teaches at Shimna Integrated College, Newcastle, wrote the childrenrsquos book over ten years ago when his grandfather, Joseph Milligan, died.Ciaran wrote The Wizard and I to help explain to his eldest daughter, Aurora, why he was so upset and hoped that it might also help other children.ldquoThe book is aimed at helping children understand grief associated with losing a loved one, said Ciaran.ldquoAurora was very young when I lost my grandfather and she couldnrsquot understand why I was sad.ldquoShe just wasnrsquot sure what was going on, it was the first time she had seen me this way and my we Colleen encouraged me to write it all down and hopefully it would help her understand, and it did.ldquoHowever, we didnrsquot actually publish the book until last year. I launched it at the school where I teach and it went down really well, everyone loved it.ldquoBut, sadly with many children loosing members of their family through Covid- the sales of the book have seen a resurgence.The Wizard and I tells the story of a young boy who visited a wizard at the bottom of his garden every time he needed advice.Ciaran added: ldquoThe wizard was always able to answer any questions the boy had, but one day the wizard wasnrsquot there. He then had to start answering questions for himself.ldquoThe boy in the story is myself as I go to visit my grandfather. The girl in the story is my daughter. When she arrives the boy has less time to spend with the wizard, explains Ciaran.ldquoAs a boy I always enjoyed spending time with my grandfather. I was like a sponge and would soak up his answers to my many questions.ldquoSome years later I got married and had a family and didnrsquot have as much time to visit my grandfather until one day he wasnrsquot there any more.Ciaran says the book, which was designed to bring about a conversation about the topic of dying, can benefit adults too.ldquoMy daughter also illustrated the book. When she heard the story she started to draw how she pictured it. When it all came together it was perfect, he remarked.The dad-of-two hopes the book will facilitate big le changes, particularly in the current climate with older generations taking the biggest impact of Covid-.He said: ldquoI think now wersquove been gted more and more time with our families and lots of people are using that time to read to their kids so I think the book is perfect for this current situation.ldquoWhen it was first launched a lot of people asked who was the target audience and who was it geared towards. Initially it was for primary school children but I also had parents email me to tell me it was therapy for them.ldquoI think that with more of our older people passing away, the book will hopefully help families with young children understand it all.The Wizard and I is available to purchase on Amazon..prettyPhoto

title: Construction work on housing scheme resumes at Downe site
story: WORK has resumed on a major public housing scheme in Downpatrick.Contractors were forced to leave the former Downe Hospital site in March due to the coronavirus pandemic but are now back building much-needed homes on behalf of Clanmill Housing.An initial  homes are being built as part of the major social housing project at the site where around  new homes could eventually be constructed. The homes are being built at a sprawling site which borders four main roads.The redevelopment of the former hospital site includes a range of housing types including apartments, two and three storey homes and bungalows.It is also understood that the former hospital and canteen building behind it, which are both listed buildings, have been incorporated into the development plan as apartment blocks.The main entrance into the former hospital complex, off Pound Lane, will remain, while itrsquos understood that a new entrance is also proposed on the Ardglass Road side of the old Downe site.Downpatrick councillor Dermot Curran is pleased that contractors are back on site and hopes they are observing social distancing guidelines.He said the redevelopment will go some way towards reducing the number of people on the waiting list for social homes in Downpatrick.Cllr Curran added: ldquoThere are many families on the waiting list for social housing who are classed in the urgent need category which effectively means they are a priority for housing providers.ldquoPeople are watching construction work progress at the former hospital site and perhaps it may be possible for families to move into their new homes before the end of the year.Now that construction work has recommenced comes after Stormont communities minister Deirdre Hargey confirmed that she is to introduce legislation designed to help protect the supply of new and existing social and affordable homes.She described housing as ldquoone of her priorities and said she has great ambitions to deliver more targeted to areas in the most need.ldquoTo do this, we must ensure we have the means to deliver, the minister continued, explaining that many of the changes required to existing legislation are technical in nature.Ms Hargey said the most signicant change will be an end to the compulsory need for registered housing associations to operate a house sales scheme.The minister said there will always be many challenges on the ability to deliver new social homes such as land availability, infrastructure issues and the availability of public finance, but outlined her commitment to doing all she can to deliver for those in need.Ms Hargey continued: ldquoI am committed to working with my Executivecolleagues to deliver more housing and welcome the priority afforded in the lsquoNew Decade, New Approachrsquo document which sets out how the Executivewill enhance investment and agree a new target for social and affordable home starts.ldquoFollowing the current coronavirus crisis, economic and social recovery will be vitally important for everyone. Whilst there are challenges ahead, a technicality should not stand in our way of delivery. This legislation will help to maximise the possible investment in a key public asset.Ms Hargey added: ldquoWithout a reversal of the classication decision the number of new social homes built each year would be reduced signicantly. It would also reduce access to the funding available for affordable housing through co-ownership..prettyPhoto

title: Council staff face furlough
story: UP to  Newry, Mourne and Down Council staff could be furloughed as a result of coronavirus, it has emerged.It is believed that the move would save the local authority in the region of pound, a month, with suggestions that the organisation is currently ldquohaemorrhaging money due to a major loss of income.The local authority plans to utilise the job retention scheme with the majority of affected employees working in leisure centres, museums and arts, tourism and community facilities across the district.All these facilities have been closed since mid March as a result of the lockdown.The local authority has confirmed that it will make use of the coronavirus job retention scheme for employees who work in services where there has been a loss of income and who cannot be redeployed.The council is insisting that, at this stage, it does not know how exactly many employees will be impacted.It is understood that some politicians have been informed about the plans to furlough council staff and are confident the employees can retain their jobs when the ious centres and community facilities reopen.Politicians are also supportive of the councilrsquos senior management team for doing all it can to maintain key services during the pandemic and its key role in helping spearhead the community response on the ground.In addition, politicians say they recognise that prudent financial management is critically important in the current climate, given the challenges that lie ahead.News that up to  staff could be furloughed comes amid increasing concern that many local authorities across Northern Ireland that are losing hundreds of thousands of pounds each month may potentially have to look at reducing some services as a result of the pandemic.While many councils do not have major cash reserves, Newry, Mourne and Down Council is reported to be in a much healthier position than most.The Northern Ireland Local Government Associationmdash the umbrella body for the Provincersquos  councils mdash has warned of a ldquocash crisis for local councils as a result of the pandemic.The organisation said councils have gone beyond their remit, giving out , emergency food parcels and opening leisure centres to facilitate this operation.NILGA chief executive Derek McCallan said the organisation is expecting to see councils lose poundm in the non-payment of rates during the current financial year in addition to monthly losses.ldquoThat really points to one thing, cessation or a severe reduction in services, he continued.NILGA wants the Treasury to provide the same financial package it has have given English councils, which translates to around poundm for Northern Ireland. The organisation may also ask the Treasury to underwrite unpaid rates.Mr McCallan added: ldquoRecovery in many cases would be severely haltedthe very facilities and support to get the economy back again are severely restricted or donrsquot exist.Confirmation that Newry, Mourne and Down Council is using the furlough scheme comes after Stormont communities minister Deirdre Hargey said her officials have been working with local authorities to understand the extent to which they can manage the Covid- situation by making use of the job retention scheme. She insisted that her priorities were ensuring that the rights of workers were respected and protecting jobs.The minister added: ldquoThis is a very dficult time for everybody. Our  councils provide very important s and services, continuing to do so during this emergency and looking ahead councils need to be ready to play their part in the economic recovery.A spokesman for Newry, Mourne and Down Council confirmed that the organisation will avail of the coronavirus job retention scheme.He explained that it will apply to employees who work in services where there is loss of income due to the Covid- pandemic and who cannot be redeployed to do other work.The spokesman added: ldquoThis falls in line with guidance from the Department for Communities. At the moment, it is not yet known how many employees will be affected..prettyPhoto

title: Cyclists Zwifting in virtual races
story: SO what is this new craze  Virtual cycling has been about for quite a few years and is basically riding your bicycle on a trainer in a virtual world.There are many apps and s available but the most popular is Zwt. This gaming  is an ever developing technology that makes training a lot more bearable and safer during those cold dark winter nights.With Zwt providing social rides, workouts, structured programmes and competitive racing, it has something for every cyclist mdash and, recently, runners too mdash all from the comfort of your home.So obviously when socialdistancing and lockdown struck, the footfall on Zwt rocketed. I suddenly noticed Shimna Wheelers numbers were increasing, from three or four of us to over a dozen.All were using it for dferent reasons. Alex McMath, Ronan Kelly, Jimmy McVeigh and myself were trying to maintain fitness and, with the aid of other apps, to socialise while riding and basically enabling a virtual club ride during lockdown. To fit in with family le these normally occur early morning or late evening.Along with Kieran Connolly, Brian McLornan and Andrew Porter, we are involved in racing leagues organised by Newry Wheelers and Cycling Ireland. The Cycling Ireland league races are broadcast live on Saturday mornings on YouTube.On the racing side, there has been plenty of banter between club members regarding weight and power. The races are seriously competitive, as they usually run in conjunction with other nationsrsquo leagues, and are pretty punishing on the body.Each of us knows our limits but with some choice words of encouragement via headphones during races, these limits can be surpassed. Jimmy is usually on the receiving end of the stick but generally backs it up in the races. Brian is beginning to settle into this new style of racing and improving with every outing.On our latest outing in the Newry League, only Kieran, Brian and myself made the start line and after a measured effort off the start we all ended up in the same group on the road, which was perfect.With the course being flat it was of utmost importance to stay in the draft of the group to preserve energy. Irsquom first to admit that both Kieran and Brian are much stronger riders than myself but with more experience on Zwt I was able to hang onto the group for longer than I expected.The three of us worked hard within the group, but with only six kilometres left we had slipped off the back of our group. I knew I was nearly done and with one last big effort Kieran and myself managed to close the gap to the group and Kieran and Brian were back in business.I was toast and reduced to riding to the finish alone, while the other lads were still firmly in the mix. They both had learnt their lesson and rode the last six kilometres well up in the group, covering every move.By the time the final sprint came Brian had recovered and shot out of the group to take the honours.Kieran rolled in a few places behind him, having succeeded in putting in a great sht during the whole race. I finished a couple of minutes down, but happy that I was able to help for a change. The next round will hopefully see a bigger Shimna turnout.Danny Carville, Barry Fettes, John Irwin and Marty McIlmail are involved in structured programmes and have found the daily training process very helpful during lockdown.One member, Brian Spence, is even using Zwt to recover from a skiing injury, while Lavelle Grant and Johnny Ward have just joined the ranks.Many other local clubs mdash such as Dromara, Newry, Killinchy, Ards and North Down mdash are experiencing similar interest due to the uncertainty of real cycling events this year.There is a lot of interaction between them and good communication, to the point that I believe it has made the whole Irish cycling community stronger and closer than it has been for a long time, helped mainly by the Zwt Community Team Irelandproviding a national sense of belonging in these dficult times.With riders from every county and of every ability itrsquos a credit to the likes of Alan Campbell, from Dromara, who has become heavily involved with the development of ZCTIrl, that this community is increasing daily.Of course Zwt is a global  and each country has its own community, but I believe that the Irish one is as strong as any in the world.Zwt is also being put to other good uses, with hundreds of people using the  to raise money for frontline services across the globe in this time of need.A few North Down members and myself helped raise more than pound, for the Ulster Hospital by riding the hardest course available on Zwt in around six hours. Painful, but well worth the effort.With the current situation worldwide, the cycling community is enjoying having some sort of sporting normality mdashyou call riding events with some of your heroes normality.The professional teams have followed suit and can be found riding around the same virtual world as us amateurs, training, racing and doing guest rides with their followers.There are not too many sports that can say that..prettyPhoto

title: Dundrum chef cooks his way to final of Great British Menu
story: DUNDRUM chef Alex Greene has booked his place through to the coveted  Great British Menu banquet.The  year-old stunned the judges on Monday nightrsquos finals competition with a potato-based dish starter dish inspired by Belfast-born CS Lewisrsquo The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe childrenrsquosrsquo book.Alex celebrated once more by picking up host, Susan Calman, and swinging her round ndash much to the comediennersquos delight.He first started off his culinary career as a  year-old washing dishes in the Buckrsquos Head restaurant in his home village.Having once worked in Claridgersquos in London and also run his own restaurant, Top Nosh, in Annalong, Alex ed to Deanes EIPIC restaurant in Belfast, where he had worked previously, and helped it retain its Michelin star for the fth year.His dish of onion jelly, pickled onions, five dferent types of potato, a four-cheese custard, and truffle, served in a wardrobe, was described by the judges as ldquoa sophisticated, sexy, sensual masterpiece. Each judge awarded Alex a perfect score of .He will be cooking the rest of his menu for the judges this week as the Northern Ireland regional winner.It was Alexrsquos second attempt to get to the final and the banquet as he had competed in last yearrsquos regional competition.He spoke of his joy of securing his place at the banquet to celebrate childrenrsquos literature.ldquoItrsquos been an unreal journey on Great British Menu and to represent Northern Ireland at the banquet for the starter is an absolute honour, he said.ldquoThank you to everyone for the support and messages, I have been overwhelmed and humbled.Michael Deane, chef patron of the Deanersquos group, called Alex ldquoworld class and thanked Alexrsquos team in EIPIC for their support in helping with his menu.Alex is the eldest son of Mark and Glynis Greene. His father said he was ldquobeyond proud of Alexrsquos achievements.The family suffered a major tragedy when Alexrsquos youngest brother, Paul, who has a twin brother David, died in a farm accident nearly three years ago.Mr Greene said: ldquoIrsquom proud of all my sons but Alex just had the taste of cooking at an early age and Alisonfrom the Bucks Head saw something in him and he worked away at it.ldquoI keep him going that he got it all from me as I love cooking but it was his own work. He was always good at cooking and did well at Home Economics at school. He just had it in him.A former student of Kilkeel High School, Alex studied catering in college before he began to work in restaurants and travelling and working all over the world in pursuit of his culinary career.Mr Greene said: ldquoAlex kept focusing on his food and learning all he could. Itrsquos all his own work, he kept pushing himself to be better. He never took the easy road, always the hard road. Once he opened his own restaurant, he realised after that he really wanted to do fine dining and thatrsquos when he ed to Deanes. Hersquos put his heart and his soul into the work there.He remarked how proud he was that his sonrsquos kind and supportive personality also shone through in the programme.ldquoAll of my boys are the same. If they see someone down, they wouldnrsquot revel in anyonersquos downfall, said Mr Greene.ldquoAlex would be the first to help someone and I noticed that on the programme as he went to help one of his competitors. He still goes to cut his grannyrsquos grass for her when he has a day off, thatrsquos just the type of him.Alex has recently started to serve specially-delivered dinners to discerning customers in their own homes during the lockdown. The service has been booked out over recent days.Dundrum will be hoping that Alex can secure another dish for Northern Ireland at the Great British Menu banquet..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C May 13%2C 2000
story: CROSSGAR ndash Furious politicians have this week accused Water Service officials of treating local ratepayers with contempt.They are outraged the Department of Environment has started work on a highly controversial scheme to pump raw sewage from Crossgar to Killyleagh for treatment with only token consultation.Councillors from both areas say they are astounded the move to begin work on the pound.m scheme was taken ldquowithout meaningful consultation and have called on Water Service chiefs to organise an urgent public meeting to spell out details of the plan.They say they had no prior warning that a contract to lay the pipeline had been awarded and that preparation for the main pipe laying scheme started a few weeks ago.DoE chiefs drew up the plan last year to ease pressure on the existing treatment plant in Crossgar, to help cure a major smell problem and allow the village to expand. They also claimed the existing plant in Killyleagh is operating well below capacity and can easely accommodate with sewage from Crossgar.But local councillors Sam Osborne and Albert Colmer have been highly critical of the DoErsquos attitude towards people in the Crossgar and Killyleagh areas and say that in a supposed era of open Government and accountability, the Departmentrsquos attitude is nothing short of ldquodeplorable and diabolical.ARDGLASS ndash A former primary school could be developed as a new community facility in Ardglass, it has emerged this week.Education chiefs say they are prepared to hand over the former Ardglass Primary School at the Downpatrick Road to the local Development Association after years of neglect.The school, which closed its doors over  years ago, was to have been developed as a new library facility, and while education chiefs claim this plan is not dead yet, they are prepared to allow the former school to be redeveloped by the local group.In addition, East Down Institute officials are understood to be interested in providing outreach classes in Ardglass and local councillor Dermot Curran says he is ldquodelighted there is now movement on the future of the old building.He has unveiled plans to hold an urgent meeting between the South Eastern Education and Library Board, the Ardglass Development Association, Down Council and the East Down Institute, to discuss a way forward.CLOUGH ndash An elderly woman was the victim of a terrying ordeal last week when masked men tied her up at her Clough home for four hours.The two intruders broke into the pensionerrsquos home at around .am on Sunday morning, tying her feet and hands before demanding money and then ransacking her house.The lady eventually managed to free herself at around am and sought help from a neighbour who reported the incident to police. She had not suffered any physical injury.It is believed that the two men made off without taking anything from the house. One is described as being rsquo tall, wearing a navy pullover and jeans. The second was rsquo tall and wore a maroon pullover and jeans.BALLYHORNAN ndash Down District could soon boast another of the provincersquos premier beaches.That is the view of local councillor Dermot Curran, who believes Down Councilrsquos recent decision to purchase Ballyhornan beach marks an important step forward for the picturesque area on the East Down coast.Council chiefs plan to carry out improvement work at the beach which Mr Curran hopes will receive the prestigious European Union blue flag status.The local councillor, who is also head of Down Councilrsquos Economic Development Committee, believes improvement work will entice more visitors and local people to the Ballyhornan area.But he believes development work should not be confined solely to the beach and hopes the local authority will be able to secure grant aid to help transform other parts of the small village.Mr Curran said since Down Council took control of Tyrella beach, the area was transformed with visitor numbers shooting through the roof.BALLYNAHINCH ndash A recent spate of burglaries across Ballynahinch has sparked police appeals for help from members of the public.Burglars wreaked havoc last week at East Down Institutersquos Ballynahinch campus when they damaged five vending machines and smashed a number of windows.The break-in at the Church Street premises took place sometime before .am last Monday morning and a substantial sum of money was taken from the vending machines.On the same morning, detectives were called to the scene of a break-in at the White Horse Hotel on the townrsquos High Street. Thieves made off with a quantity of alcohol and a pay phone.Meanwhile a derelict shirt factory was broken into on Windmill Street, some time between last Wednesday night and the following morning.SAINTFIELD ndash Travelling from Enniskillen to Dublin may not be an enviable task but when your mode of transport is a small boat the journey becomes a feat of daring.But Saintfieldrsquos Ian Harvey has risen to the challenge and is setting out next month to brave over  miles of canals and waterways in a charity row with a dference.Ian is lsquoputting his oar inrsquo to raise pound, for the Fields of Le Trust so it can build a primary school in rural Uganda.The Armagh-based charity has already built two schools in the area, preparing young people for employment and teaching them how to farm.Ian was inspired to carry out some fund-raising after experiencing first hand the traumas of le in the Third World while working as a reporter in Zambia and Zimbabwe.ldquoThe greatest problem I came across was the spread of AIDS in these countries, he explained. ldquoTraditionally, men in these countries have several wives and sometimes mistresses too which means the disease can sp quickly ndash around  per cent of the population are affected and many children have been left orphaned at an early age.KILLYLEAGH ndash A book and special exhibition celebrating  years of Christianity in Killyleagh was launched at a ceremony in the town on Thursday night.The vice-chairman of Down Council, Albert Colmer, formally opened the exhibition of photos and artefacts that continues until the weekend at the Bridge Community Centre in the town.The book charts the history of the four main churches in the town in the words and photos of lay members of the two Presbyterian congregations, St Johnrsquos Church of Ireland and St Maryrsquos Catholic Church who came together under the title of the Killyleagh Christian Heritage Committee.DOWNPATRICK ndash Contractors moved in this week to start work on the first site to be developed at the new pound million IDB Industrial Park in Downpatrick.The project involves the construction of a new poundm enterprise site for Down Business Centre and is expected to be completed within  months.The business centrersquos chairman, Owen OrsquoConnor, was there with LEDU and Down Council officials to watch and sign the contract papers with Mr Eugene Walker, of Maghera Construction.ldquoThis is a milestone day for Down District, said Mr OrsquoConnor. ldquoOne of the major drawbacks we have had in attracting investment to this area was the lack of suitable industrial and service space. Now that we have a major site we can look forward with more confidence to winning some extra business and job-creating opportunities for the district..prettyPhoto

title: It’s brought a wee community in Kilmore a lot closer
story: A KILMORE singer songwriter is entertaining neighbours and fans around the world from his garden during the coronavirus lockdown.Eddie Booth may be more accustomed singing to pub goers in Belfast, but now he is now lting the spirits of thousands of people during his live shows every Saturday night.The  year-old, who once turned down an offer to play a series of gigs from concert promoter, Jim Aiken, now reaches fans from as far away as America, Brazil and Argentina.Eddie, who calls his half-hour-long shows Live From The Lamplight, performs covers from his idols such as Neil Diamond, John Lennon and John Denver.ldquoI have a regular Facebook following each week who watch on as I entertain my neighbours and poke a little fun at myself, said Eddie.ldquoIt began a few weeks into the lockdown when I plugged my guitar into an amp I put out the window and played a few songs from the lamppost at the corner of my garden.ldquoThe neighbours came out and stood in their gardens to listen. We are all doing social distancing, but my vocals could be heard way down the road. Itrsquos just grown from there.He said: ldquoItrsquos brought a wee community a lot closer together. I couldnrsquot be any prouder of the folk who live in Kilmore. They have been exceptional supporters every week as the show goes out.ldquoThey dress up and bring out their tables and enjoy the show. There is a terric community spirit abounding and everyone is looking out for each other. It makes for a terric atmosphere.Eddie, who is also a Sunday School teacher, says Facebook supporters and neighbours alike have left thousands of messages of support and itrsquos this which keeps him going.Whilst Eddie used to be crippled by anxiety and depression, he bares no visible scars from his ordeal.Originally from the Braniel estate in east Belfast, he went from zero to hero battling hard to overcome his poor mental health, but says his le is only just beginning now.ldquoWhen I was in my late teens I spent  weeks in hospital to treat some underlying mental health issues. My father visited me twice a day while I was there. I wasnrsquot in a good place mentally.ldquoWith in a few short years I was on the streets. While I was homeless I was attacked one night and badly beaten up. I was left for dead but have survived and I made it nonetheless.He added that plans are afoot to make a film about his le and his remarkable journey to success.ldquoIrsquove been performing since I was  and have played in so many places and I know how important music is as a way to make people feel better and lt their spirits.Itrsquos no surprise to learn that Eddie, who also plays Gospel music, has been entertaining residents at nursing homes and hospitals over the last  years. He says the hardest part of the lockdown is not being able to visit them.ldquoI always come away feeling a lot better than I did before I went to visit them. Just to spend an hour among these people puts you in a better frame of mind. I consider them my friends.Like all good artists, Eddie has some terric helpers with his weekly shows.He said: ldquoAoe Boyle is  years old and performs a song or two during our weekly shows. She is a very gted singer. Blake Harwood is responsible for the filming. He is currently studying media and I think he has a great future ahead of him.ldquoWe have planned a VC day. Thatrsquos something like VE Day celebrations but stands for Victory over the Coronavirus. We hope to hold a big party when all this is over.At pm every Thursday Eddie performs a special gig to coincide with the closure of all bars, hotels and restaurants during the Covid- pandemic.Last week he performed Percy Frenchrsquos The Mountains of Mourne from the grounds of Slieve Donard Hotel Resort and Spa. Tomorrow evening will see him visit another local hotel before he takes on the rigours of his regular Saturday night Kilmore show..prettyPhoto

title: Memories of Tyrella point to point
story: THIS week we look back at the East Down Foxhounds point-to-point meeting that took place at the Corbett family estate at Tyrella on Saturday, March , .As usual in those days the opening race on the card was the Alan Dunlop Confined Hunt Race. Only four of the nine entries went to post with Newcastle ride Tom Newsam setting off in the lead on his own Miss Lennihan, followed by Colin McBratney on Belle Lady, owned and trained at Strangford by Joe Magee.Belle Lady came down and victory went to Midnight Auburn, owned and ridden by Downpatrickrsquos Gerry Lavery, whose son, Declan, is one of todayrsquos top local amateur riders. Miss Lennihan took second as Paddy Fitzsimons had to pull up on Heatherrsquos Braes.The winner was trained by Gerryrsquos brother, Brian, who works for Jeremy Maxwell at Ballee. For Gerry, this was his sole success in the saddle.The third race of the day was the Rearsquos Emporium Open which resulted in another nice local success for Nightmaster, owned and trained at Erenagh by John McCauley and ridden by his son Denis.David Wilsonrsquos Wremando, ridden by Laurence Millar, was second and third past the judge, David Shillington, from Dromara, was Blinky Bill in the colours of Comberrsquos Dessie Osborne, the former good amateur Paul Larkin being in the saddle.On the days leading up to this meeting, the dogs were barking, as they say, for a horse called Supplementary Sam. This horse took part in the fourth race, the Andi Grand Prix qualier and, with Rathfriland jockey Leo Gracey in the saddle, made all at the running to come home four s clear of Glen Keys, ridden by Paul Larkan, and Bentra Road, ridden by Tom Howley. Frankie Fitzsimons was fourth on Davy Blackrsquos Anns Penny.The winner, making his debut, ran in the colours of Rathfrilandrsquos Sam McKee, better known as Uel, who told me not all that long ago, that they arrived at the track that day in a makesht horse box and parked beside some of the lorries from top stables.The East DownshireOpen Farmers Race went to Grange Valleyrsquo, owned and trained by former good amateur Ballymenarsquos Samy Patton and ridden by Robert Steele, who rode all his runners. Second was Ballymoney farrier John Mawhinneyrsquos Motalee, ridden by Denis Macauley who in later years bred Brave Inca. Strahane Last took third ahead of False Modesy, ridden by Ballygowanrsquos I Kerr for Tom Kerr.This was double success for Lisburn vet-surgeon Robert Steele, as he had earlier won the second race of the day, the R E Hamilton Hunter Chase Championship Qualier, value pound, on Eurowin. Second was Meadow Hawk, ridden by William Gault, from Randalstown, with Downpatrickrsquos painter Kieran McLoughin third on the Leo McGrady-owned Le Bambino.Irsquom not sure where I watched all the races, but I do recall that I went to the second fence on the course to watch the final race, the Ashley Bar Mares Maiden Race. In those days the fence was an open ditch and permanent.The leader going into the fence was Miss Alex, trained by Victor Robinson at Portadown and ridden by Tom Howley. The six year old never lted, firing her rider onto the ground, and in the process brought down Colin McBratney on More Cloud. Somehow the other  runners avoided Howley as the race progressed.The eventual winner was Bonnetys Bridge, a rare ride and a sole career win for Don Ferris from Poyntzpass, Newry, who is now the father-in-law of top local amateur Mark OrsquoHare. Second past the post was Dalaray, owned by Banbridge farmer Robert Mulligan and the mount of Ian Buchanan, who was a dentist in those days. Third was Staboe Lady, ridden by her owner, M CampbellThe meeting was run under the stewardship of Craig Caven and Mrs Doreen Johnston. The hon secretary was Ballydrainrsquos Jim Pooler, while his son, Chris, was the announcer. The clerks of the course were Denis Macauley and Tom Edgar and among the honorary surgeons was Mr Alan Archbold from Seaforde. In those days Billy Cromie from Clough was well known as the board marker.Among the advertisers were Charles Keown, Renault dealer Royal Ascot Roadhouse, Carryduff Seaforde Transport CJ Foy MPS, Irish Street, Downpatrick The Old Tom Bar, Castlewellan Watt and McBriar Ltd, Saintfield Abbey Grill, Downpatrick and Irwinrsquos Superfoods, Ballynahinch.Following on from the only career wins of Lavery and Ferris, it is interesting to record that in  Craig Caven, Ardglass farmer and long time master of the East Downs, was able to achieve a long held ambition to ride in a point-to-point when partnering Nightmasterrsquo, a course specialist owned and trained by John Macauley, in the opening Alan Dunlop Confined Hunt Race.It was a very wet and windy day mdash only eight of the  entries took part mdash but Craig won from ldquoTullumgrange, bred and owned by Ardglass farmer Dick McConvey, and ridden by Darragh Cross rider Paul McMahon. Red Gazette, owned by Frances Haw from Ballynahinch, came third.Felix Burns, who is now over , from Rossglass, had a runner in the race called Bright Spree VI. It is also interesting that More Cloud, ridden by Colin McBratney, won the concluding race, the Joseph Walls Mares Maiden Race, from Comber owner Elizabeth OrsquoPreyrsquos Yankee Lass and No Time for Tears, in the colours of Drumaness owner Phil Kimber, this one ridden by Tom Howley,Other runners in the race were Eddie Armstrongrsquos Barcora Maidrsquo, ridden by Yvonne Armstrong, both from Saintfield, Craig Queen, owned by Tom Stronge from Killinchy, and Turkish River VI, owned by Strangfordrsquos Dickie Murphy, the mount of Paddy Fitzsimons.Liam Lennon broke a bone in his foot when colliding with a rail on Sam Hamiltonrsquos OrsquoBriens Daughter and had to be helped of his mount.It was sad to learn that former Downpatrick flat jockey, Michael Mathers, has passed away recently..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle gondola tourism project edges closer
story: PLANS for a poundm investment in a flagship tourism project in Newcastle have received formalsupport from the Northern Ireland Executive.Over poundm of new funding for infrastructure, regeneration and tourism projects across Northern Ireland has been made available by the Stormont administration to match-fund a number of so-called City Deals.The City Deals are designed to provide local authorities with packages of funding and decision making powers to boost their respective economies through large development projects.Newry, Mourne and Down Council, which is part of the Belfast Region City Deal, is spearheading the Mournes Gateway project with the series of ambitious plans including a gondola ride into the heart of the mountains.The ambitious proposal mdash designed to revolutionise tourist facilities in the resort and signicantly increase visitor numbers mdash also includes an Alpine coaster ride enabling people to hurtle down the side of the mountain on a single track in a buggy.Other aspects of the scheme include an elevated tree top walk in Tollymore Forest Park, a new visitor centre and bird hide at the Murlough Nature Reserve and a new bridge constructed under the main Kilkeel Road at the Bloody Bridge on the outskirts of the town.Consultants appointed by the local authority to look at developing the resortrsquos visitor infrastructure have also come up with proposals for the Islands Park, with upgrades planned for existing car parks, alongside new public toilet provision.There are also proposals to reduce the the tree line in Donard Forest on the slopes of the Mournes, with a lsquogreen travel networkrsquo which would allow visitors to hire bicycles and electric bikes to make their way round ious attractions is also suggested.Confirmation of the NI Executiversquos funding for a series of schemes across the Province was confirmed last week, with the poundm Stormont investment package viewed as a crucial component in helping rebuild the economy post-coronavirus.The ious proposals which form the core of the Mournes Gateway project have already been discussed with the National Trust, Forest Service, Environment Agency and other key agencies, with confirmation of NI Executive funding welcomed by Mournes councillor, Willie Clarke.He said it is very signicant that the Executive has weighed in with its support for the Newcastle project as part of the Belfast Region City Deal.He described the government support as an ldquoimportant milestone on the road to delivering the flagship tourism proposal which, he said, has the potential to firmly cement Newcastlersquos place as a key visitor destination.But Cllr Clarke says the Gateway project is not just about visitors, explaining it is also about catering for the needs of local people, with the NI Executive funding representing another critical piece in the development proposal jigsaw.ldquoIt is my understanding that the projectrsquos business case has been submitted, he said.ldquoWhat we are talking about is ensuring that we deliver a sustainable tourism venture, one that will also focus on the arearsquos pre-Christian and Christian heritage and also Newcastlersquos industrial heritage.ldquoIt is important to look at the overall picture of what is envisaged. There are plans for sustainable transport projects including a park and ride scheme to bring visitors into the centre of the resort with the scheme similar to the one which operates during the resortrsquos international Festival of Flight.Cllr Clarke says the Gateway project encourages people to walk and cycle more and believes that the multi-million pound scheme can provide a signicant boost for the wider district economy.He said while people are rightly preoccupied with coronavirus at the moment, work is continuing to look at the future of tourism development across the region.He added: ldquoNewcastle can play its part and we all hope that the Gateway project will not only put the resort on the map, but wider South Down area. The scheme has the potential to create new hotel and retail development, creating jobs and boosting the economy.ldquoThe project is people-driven and providing facilities for them. It is also vital that was is created is used all-year-round, not just during the traditional tourism season. The focus is also in on making the most of the natural environment that we have in Newcastle and the surrounding area.A Newry, Mourne and Down Council spokesman said that the Belfast Region City Deal represents a major investment.He said in the Newry, Mourne and Down area, the investment proposals focus on the Mournes Gateway project and several schemes in the Newry area, including a city centre regeneration project, new theatre and conference facility and southern relief road.ldquoFunding is also being made available for digital infrastructure enhancements and enhanced skills and employability provision across the region, said the spokesman.He said the vision from the City Deal investment was to deliver inclusive growth, deliver up to , more jobs and increase the value of goods and services produced in the area by poundm annually..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle man’s extraordinary job post at the South Pole
story: IMAGINE looking out of your kitchen window and seeing a humpback whale idly swimming by, or a small team of seals at play in the water.Therersquos snow and ice everywhere, animals outnumber humans, noise is completely muted but yet you have never felt more alive or connected to the world.Thatrsquos the extraordinary experience Newcastle man Kit Adams enjoyed when he took up a job offer which saw him as postmaster at the Port Lockroy research station on Goudier Island.Itrsquos located off the west side of the Antarctic Peninsula, more commonly known as the South Pole, and is one of the most remote places in the world.The  year-old mountaineer lived and worked with a small team of people over four months in what has become an important heritage site and a tourist destination for people who want to see the thriving penguin community.Employed by the UK Antarctic Heritage Trust, Kit handled the postcards sent by hundreds of holidaymakers on Antarctic cruises who visit the island and claim to have set foot on earthrsquos most southerly point.Back at his familyrsquos home in Newcastle, Kit has had time to reflect on what the experience meant to him.ldquoThe one thing that became clear to me is that itrsquos the type of environment that I want to spend more time in, said Kit, who coped with freezing temperatures of up to minus seven degrees fahrenheit.ldquoIt really affirmed what I thought I wanted to do, and thatrsquos spending more time in the polar regions. Itrsquos just so unique and dferent to Northern Ireland.ldquoWe have got the Mournes on our doorstep mdash thatrsquos what really got me into enjoying the outdoors. Growing up here, snow is always a novelty, which only comes every now and again. When it does, you try and make the most of it. Once I moved to university in Scotland, snow was much more regular thing and something I enjoyed.ldquoI definitely prefer the cold to the heat I canrsquot handle the heat at all to be honest. If you are somewhere cold, there is always something you can do about it mdash put on an extra layer mdash but in the heat I just struggle.A former pupil of Newcastle Primary School and Down High School in Downpatrick, Kit had been to the South Pole three times before he applied for the job at Port Lockroy. He made the application due to a recommendation from a friend who had already worked there.Kitrsquos academic background mdash he has a Geography degree from the University of Dundee and a Masters degree in Polar and Alpine Change from the University of Sheffield mdash made him a perfect fit for the job.ldquoGoing to Port Lockroy was such a unique opportunity that I jumped at the chance, he said.ldquoWhen we arrived last November, we couldnrsquot get onto the island as there was some sea ice. When we did get on, it was completely covered in snow. As the days went by, more rock was becoming exposed as the snow with the ice was melting. At the end of the season, there really wasnrsquot any snow left on the island.Despite being in what of the great expanses of ice and water on the planet, Kitrsquos world on the island suddenly became very small.ldquoThe island is really only the size of a football pitch and half of that is not accessible, he said.There is a Nissan hut where all the resident staff, and any visiting staff, live and work, a boat shed, which is a historic building, and Bransfield House, named after the Irish Antarctic sailor and explorer, Edward Bransfield. This houses the islandrsquos only shop, post office and museum.Kit explained: ldquoItrsquos quite a simplistic lestyle. There was no social media, no great phone connectivity, basic work emails, no running water or mains electricity, but it was nice to get away from wi-fi and it a quite peaceful le in many ways.ldquoYou are with the rest of the team [resident team of five], day in, day out,   on a tiny island and you need to be able to work and live in this small space with the same people every day. We had no means of getting off the island and had to do all our cooking, cleaning, etc. Therersquos quite a lot of work and maintenance to do and yoursquore always busy so you didnrsquot really have a lot of downtime. We got one day off in every .The high point for Kit was the stunning environment and being surrounded by all kinds of wildle.ldquoThere was loads of wildle, several penguin species such as the Gentoo, Chinstrap and Aediles, he said.ldquoYou can really see the penguins transition throughout the season. At the start they are gathering stones and building nests, by the end of the season, their new chicks are learning to swim. There are all sorts of flying birds like skuas, gulls, Southern Giant petrels, and cormorants. Sometimes you would see all kinds of fish, jelly fish, and ious types of seals and whales.ldquoYou could be washing the dishes and see a humpback whales outside. It was just ridiculous but absolutely wonderful at the same time.Spending Christmas at Port Lockroy was also special to Kit and the team as they had the pleasure of a day off and a chance of seeing the tiny island from a dferent perspective.Kit said: ldquoThere was a cruise ship nearby who kindly offered us a couple of kayaks. We manged to kayak around the island on Christmas day which was a great experience.While hersquos happy to be home with his family mdash dad Colin, mum Janette and brother Nick , who is also back home having left his former job in the Swiss Alps mdash Antarctica still has its hold over Kit.ldquoSimply being there is something that I do miss but the people I was there with were truly wonderful and I got on fantastically well with them, he says. ldquoItrsquos a bit strange being with them for so long and then everyone just goes their separate ways.ldquoEverything is up in the air at the moment but I really would love to go back..prettyPhoto

title: Soccer over
story: THE local soccer season has come to an end with unfinished business left on the books.Amateur League and Newcastle League officials have brought their seasons to a juddering halt without promotion and relegation issues being decided.Both leagues made their decisions after consulting with their clubs and although no one goes up and no one goes down, there are clear winners and losers.In the Amateur League the biggest losers are Ballynahinch Olympic, who were bidding to become champions of the Premier Division for the first time.They had an eight-point lead at the top of the table when football was suspended two months ago, although nearest rivals Crumlin Star and East Belfast had plenty of games in hand.Also on the losersrsquo list are Dromara Village, who were lying third in Division A and vying for promotion to the top flight.The biggest winners are Drumaness Mills, who have been spared relegation from the Premier Division, despite being rock bottom without a point to their name.Also saved are Downpatrick FC, who were eight points adrt at the bottom of Division A, and Ballynahinch United, who were at the foot of Division A and odds-on to make the .The only section to have an outcome is in Division C where top of the table Rosemount have been promoted. They have completed their fixtures and cannot be overtaken.In the Newcastle League, the biggest losers are Ardglass, who will have nothing to show for their efforts, despite being  points clear at the top of the Premier Division.Celtic Bhoys Academy have already been declared the winners of Division  because they cannot be caught. Division , which was headed by Celtic Bhoys Academy before the lockdown, will remain unfinished, as will the Purdy Cup.The Bobby Dalzell Cup final, between Killough and Ballynahinch Olympic Town, and the Harry Clarke Cup final, featuring Celtic Bhoys and Ballynagross, will be played at the start of next season.Newcastle League secretary Alan Craig said the announcement would bring a ldquolevel of certainty and closure to the clubs.In a letter sent out to clubs he said: ldquoThe committee believed it was the correct procedure to ask the clubs for their input.ldquoWe understand these are challenging times and, in any case, our primary concern would always have been the welfare of the clubs, players, match officials, volunteers and any supporters during this unprecedented period.Mr Craig was unable to give the clubs a start date for the new season.ldquoThe committee have been in constant dialogue and agreed that setting a date for the new season to begin is just not possible under the current Government guidelines being issued. Once we are in a position to do so, we will issue a further statement on a possible start date for season  , he said.Mr Craig did confirm that clubs would be given a % reduction in their subion fees next season as a gesture of good will.ldquoWe are aware that it will be a dficult period for everyone and the committee are in agreement that this is positive step, he added.The Amateur League has announced that it will not be asking clubs to pay their annual subscription fees next season..prettyPhoto

title: Staying here in Australia was the best and safest thing for us
story: A YOUNG local couple now living in Australia say they feel more protected from the Covid- threat than at home.Gareth Ricefrom Downpatrick and his  year-old partner, Emmah Feenan, from Ardglass, have been living in a Sydney suburb for nearly four years.An administrator for a legal firm, Mr Rice said he and his partner ruled out ing back to Co Down when it became clear that the coronavirus outbreak had become a pandemic ndash despite other expatriates taking the opportunity to leave.He told the Recorder that they both had confidence in the strategy and the restrictions which the Australian government put in place to tackle the outbreak.ldquoI would say that most people living here are in support of what the government are doing and this is borne out by the fact that we have had only a few deaths here, Gareth said. ldquoPeople here are not demanding that everything is put back to normal as it appears to be happening in the UK.ldquoLast Thursday there were only three or four deaths for the whole of New South Wales, where we live, and thatrsquos very low when you consider the population. Whatever measures the government have put in place ndash and they were very quick to take action and order a lockdown and introduce testing ndash they seem to have worked.Gareth said they were concerned like everyone  about the outbreak, but reckoned that they would put themselves at more risk taking a flight home.He said: ldquoOnce all this happened, we did have the conversation with our families about whether or not we should go home, but to be honest, regarding all the news headlines that we have been reading about home and the rest of the UK, we weighed everything up and it seemed that the situation was much worse in the UK and Ireland.ldquoAs we were able to still continue with our jobs, it seemed staying was the best and safest solution for us.The Australian government, along with the Northern Ireland Assembly and Prime Minister Boris Johnston, this week announced plans to phase down current lockdown restrictions over the coming weeks and months. Australia has recorded only  deaths for the whole country out of , confirmed coronavirus cases.The countryrsquos plan to ensure that all people coming into the country will be forcibly quarantined was something that he believed was essential to happen.ldquoOver here, they mean what they say, said Gareth. ldquoWe have been told that for new visitors into the country will be guarded to ensure that they comply with the quarantine.Gareth said that as he and Emmah, who works in traffic control, lived in Newtown, a few miles from the centre of Sydney, they were still able to go to the beach to enjoy during the lockdown.ldquoThere are so many beaches close to us here that we are spoilt for choice, he continued. ldquoThe beaches were reopened a few weeks ago so we could go for a swim, surf, walk or run. Thatrsquos all considered part of your exercise and itrsquos to be able to enjoy that.He said people were still not allowed to sunbathe but that being able to go out to the beach made up for the lack of other social access and activity.ldquoWe have a lot of friends here, particularly other people like ourselves who are all from the same area, and we are missing out being able to meet up with them in bars and restaurants, ldquo said Gareth.ldquoWe are very fortunate that we have been able to go out to the beach on an evening after work, so it doesnrsquot feel like we are so cooped up and we both really love the outdoors le..prettyPhoto

title: Tributes paid to Bears’ chairman who loved sport
story: TOLLYMORE United FC chairman John McIlvenny passed away peacefully at his home last week after a long battle against a very debilitating illness.John was involved in the Tollymore club since its formation in  and was chairman for  of its  years. He occupied the role of secretary for the first season. Anyone that knew John would say he was first and foremost a football man.Having moved to Newcastle with his we, Josie, John soon became involved in the local football scene and went on to manage Newcastle FC.Many of us remember John playing in the old Summer League in the s for the Castlemac team and his team mates calling him Dixie after the great Everton striker Dixie Dean.A le-long Tottenham Hotspur supporter you would have thought John had a big enough cross to bear before he got involved in starting a new football club in his adopted town.A chance discussion in the summer of  led to John calling a meeting and from it Tollymore United was formed. Very soon the club appointed a manager, Clarence Robinson, and within a matter of weeks club had signed a host of players and started training.With Clarence and Sean Lavery looking after the playing side of things, John and his committee started planning off the field. The clubrsquos first presentations dinner was held in May , in the Central Park, with Northern Ireland legend Derek Dougan the guest of honour. Some of the clubs older members still talk about that night.Another first was the clubrsquos annual Christmas party for children, with John acting as Santa, and such was its popularity that committee members frequently had to rush down to the shops for more selection boxes.The club was now starting to establish itself more off the pitch than on it and the big name guests continued to arrive at the clubrsquos annual awards nights. Manchester United legend Tommy Docherty came in , Denis Law in , Liverpool legend Tommy Smith and Everton and Forest star Duncan Mackenzie in , and so it went on with John in his absolute element with Josie at his side.As the playing side of things began to improve there was nobody prouder than John when, in May , the club beat Ballycam Celtic in a play-off to win the Mourne Observer Cup and gain promotion to the Newcastle leaguersquos Premier Division.The merry-go-round of legends continued with Billy Bremner in  and the biggest name of all, Jack Charlton, arriving in  with John, proud as punch, appearing in the Belfast .In  the club had a fantastic season reaching the final of the Co Antrim Junior Shield only to lose - after conceding a golden goal. John, along with everyone , was gutted, but anyone who had been in Quinnrsquos that night would never have believed the Bears had lost.The following year the club lted the Rathmourne Cup with the second team winning the Purdy Cup and players and supporters lting the roof off the Donard Hotel in the company of Liverpoolrsquos Ian St John. What a night that was with John filling the Rathmourne Cup several times and rumours that Pete Law was required to repair the cup after a raucous night have never been confirmed or denied.Christmas  saw the Bears lting the Bobby Dalzell cup and another crazy awards night took place in the company of Emlyn Hughes.While football played a huge part in Johnrsquos le, he was very much a family man. Josie was a constant by his side at every club dinner and to everyone that knew them they were like a double act mdash terric company and great craic.John suffered a loss when his beloved Josie died, but his love of his grandchildren helped him through that dficult period. He was immensely proud of his daughter, Joanne, and loved nothing better than bringing his grandson, Callum, down to Friday night football.It was fitting that the club was able to hold its th anniversary dinner last year in the Slieve Donard Hotel where John previously worked as bar manager. John took his seat with son-in-law Mark alongside Liverpool legend Bruce Grobbelaar and it was like the good old days with John once more in his element welcoming guests and posing for pictures.It most have taken a huge effort on his part to attend but he would certainly not have missed it for anythingThe Tollymore United club, committee, players, coaches and supporters would like to offer their sincere condolences to Johnrsquos daughter Joanne, son-in-law Mark, grandchildren Callum, Clara, Alana and Harry, his sister Anne, nieces and nephews. John will be sorely missed. May he rest in peace..prettyPhoto

title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. title: comment psychology lockdown and its aftermath
story: Gerry Adams: Security veteran says pressure on the state at time of internment was ‘impossible’ thanks to IRA ‘bedlam’Heartbroken husband and father Ryan Smyth thanks friends for their support after todays funeral for Clare and Bethany - asking for privacy at this very dficult timeNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsOpinionComment: The psychology of lockdown and its aftermathProfessor Brendan Kelly of Trinity College Dublin on the mental health challenges of coping with the pandemicBy Professor Brendan KellyMonday, th May , : am""Coronavirus and the public health response it triggered have changed our worlds dramatically. For families directly affected by the virus, the past few months have involved combinations of illness, trauma, recovery and loss.Other people have spent most of the time at home, socially distancing and worrying about the future. Many have lost their jobs. Some have lost hope.The public health response to coronavirus has worked well. But while social distancing and self-isolation help reduce transmission of the virus, they also create unusual social and emotional situations with which most people are unfamiliar. " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...Quarantine has similar effects, resulting in fear of infection, frustration, boredom and annoyance at lack of information. These are psychologically challenging circumstances for everyone.Negative emotions are amplied by spending large amounts of time at home, but can be managed by careful awareness of how we feel, accepting support from other people, and looking after our diet, sleep and exercise as best as possible. Even when our movements are restricted, there is much that we can do.This week, however, just as many people adjusted to the new psychological and emotional landscape, everything changed again. Or did it Certain restrictions are being eased. Some businesses can reopen. A degree of normality is starting to .This is good news. Public health measures are working, so we can go further outside, restart the economy and get people back to work. We must still observe the public health advice, but we can finally start rebuilding our lives.Coming out of quarantine is a psychological transition as much as a physical one, so new challenges lie ahead. Some people are likely to be anxious about easing restrictions, worried about their risk of catching coronavirus or infecting others. The best advice for these people is simple: trust the public health guidance. Despite ious dferences in approaches over past months, most countries have now landed on roughly similar guidelines. Public health officials know what they are talking about. They will monitor the situation over the coming weeks. Trust them.For people who contracted coronavirus and recovered, easing the restrictions can bring additional problems with stigma, finances and tensions in relationships, as well as anger towards governments for perceived inaction. Again, these feelings are understandable and need to be recognised.But while we cannot negotiate directly with emotions, we can observe them, try not to engage, and watch them subside. Taking advantage of our new freedoms – travelling a little further, ing to work – also helps to resolve these psychological issues.Many of the problems we now face are similar to those experienced by anyone who emerges from an institution, like a hospital, after a prolonged stay: lack of confidence, uncertainty about new freedoms, and worries about the long-term psychological impact of the entire episode.How can we navigate this anxiety  There is much that we can do.First, stay informed. Read the public health advice with care. Trust it. Follow it.Second, do not be afraid. Go outsideyou are advised that you can. Physical and mental health are very closely linked. Going outside helps with both. Be sure to take steps forward.Third, take it easy. If you have not been outside in some time, take short trips to build your confidence. We need to relearn some of our old behaviours. This takes time.Emotional awareness is vital. These are very unusual circumstances at a time of unique emotional intensity. Be compassionate towards yourself and others. Take full advantage of the thaw. title: cardiff south penarth mp stephen doughty calls keir starmers labour leadership win ray hope difficult times
story: The MP for Holborn and St Pancras defeated Lisa Nandy and Rebecca Long-Baily.Mr Doughty has previously expressed his support for Sir Keir, who won on the first round of voting with . per cent of ballots cast.Stephen called Sir Keirs ascension a ray of hope, and said that the party should now turn its attention to winning elections.He said: ldquoI am so pleased that Keir Starmer has become UK Labour leader.ldquoThe ray of hope Keir represents could not come at a more critical time.ldquoHis message of unity has won over members up and down the country ndash and we need to ensure that we model that through the whole of the UK Labour Party.ldquoAnd it is clear that Labour comes out of this contest stronger, with Rebecca and Lisa running really positive campaigns.ldquoThe UK General Election result in December was devastating for Labour and we cannot repeat it."Thatrsquos why Keirrsquos campaign was all about focussing the party on winning elections. Only then can we change peoplersquos lives."Welsh Labour, and First Minister Mark Drakeford will now be working closely with Keir to ensure we win the Senedd elections next year.ldquoKeir has already shown his commitment to Wales and Welsh Labour, and personally visited Cardf South and Penarth with me just a few months ago to meet local residents.ldquoWe also need to restore peoplersquos trust in the Labour Party as a force for good - a crucial part of that is tackling antisemitism."I know that Keir has the values, vision and moral compass needed to fight for justice at home and abroad ndash and that is needed more than ever.ldquoNobody could have predicted the campaign ending in these hugely dficult circumstances - and regardless of the result, our primary thoughts at the moment are with all those affected by coronavirus, and our brilliant NHS and social care staff, and key workers up and down the country who are keeping us going and saving lives every day."The Labour Partyrsquos number one priority right now is working across party lines to help the country get through this.ldquoI am also delighted Angela Rayner has been elected our new UK Deputy Leader ndash someone who I have campaigned with on a range of issues over many years. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... went about their rounds this week.A large number of similar messages were sent to the council via social media.The Barry Waterfront Covid- Community Support Facebook group made a particular effort, title: virus decimated marie curie hospice charity income penarth
story: End of le patients who do not want to be in hospital need to be moved to a more appropriate setting, as beds in critical care units are urgently required for patients who need lesaving treatment.The charity, which relies upon public donations and fundraising events needs to raise pound million a year to continue to run its essential frontline services across Wales.However, chief executive Matthew Reed has said the charityrsquos income has been lsquodecimatedrsquo due to the outbreak.Rachel Moses-Lloyd from Marie Curie in Wales said: ldquoWhen the NHS and public need us most, we are facing huge dficulties raising our vital funds."Along with the cancellation of hundreds of high street and supermarket collections, wersquore now losing income from the closure of our charity shops and from cancelled fundraising events."The Marie Curie Cardf and the Vale Hospice in Penarth cares for around , people each year.Its manager, Sarah Lloyd-Davies, said: ldquoAcross Marie Curie we have provided care to a few terminally ill patients who have tested positive for coronavirus or are suspected of having it and do expect this to continue in future. For reasons of patient confidentiality we are not able to discuss specic cases of care from the hospice or from the community nursing care we provide.ldquoOur hospice staff and nursing teams across Cardf and the Vale are very much on the frontline and have an important job in keeping patients out of hospital to relieve pressure on the NHS. That is important now more than ever given the coronavirus crisis. The health and wellbeing of our patients, their loved ones, and our staff is our top priority and across the hospice and community we are taking steps to protect them. This includes the use of PPE and, in-line with other providers of care, including the NHS, we have amended our visiting rules at the hospice.ldquoWith regards PPE, unfortunately, our hospice and community nursing service have been facing the same issues as the NHS in terms of getting all the equipment they need. We are screening patients with a phone call before attending their homes and staff will wear the appropriate PPE equipment during every household visit. However, we can only do this when we have the right PPE equipment available and are grateful to have recently received support from our colleagues at the Cardf and the Vale University Health Board to gain access to some PPE through their supply, for which we give our thanks.ldquoHowever we are always in need of more supplies to continue to provide vital end of le care to people living with a terminal illness, especially at this dficult time. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. story: A total of  of these cases were in the Vale of Glamorgan where a further  people tested positive on Wednesday.In total  people have been tested for the virus in the Vale, of whom . per cent have tested positive.Meanwhile, the virus has claimed  more lives across Wales, meaning  have now passed away with the disease.There were  new cases of covid- reported in Wales, taking the total number of confirmed cases to ,, although the true number of cases is likely to be higher.Dr Robin Howe, Incident Director for the Novel Coronavirusoutbreak response at Public Health Wales, said: ldquoWe offer our condolences to families and friends affected, and we ask those reporting on the situation to respect patient confidentiality.ldquoPublic Health Wales has conducted more than , tests for Novel Coronaviruson more than , iniduals since the start of this outbreak.It comes as a Welsh Government minister said lockdown rules will continue into at least next week.When the UK-wide lockdown rules were announced, prime minister Boris Johnson said they would be reviewed every three weeks.Next Monday, April , marks three weeks since the announcement.But, speaking at a press conference yesterday, the Welsh Government housing and local government minister Julie James said this was too soon to lt the lockdown and the rules would remain in force in Wales into the start of next week - and possibly further.A more formal announcement on the continuation of lockdown guidelines will be given soon."These are extraordinary times, and weve taken these measures because by working together we can slow the speed of the coronavirus," Mrs James said."We will definitely be extending the guidelines, and more formal restrictions will be announced within the next few days. What I do know is that the measures will definitely stay in force after Monday."With the Easter weekend coming up, Mrs James also reiterated the importance of abiding by the rules."There are signs that these measures are having an impact," she said. "Our decisions taken this weekend will impact our lives in the future.
